author: joseph azevedo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2018
review_content: Are you a creative? Edit video? Need a back up or external working drive? Don't buy this.Example:85 GB on another USB 3.0 Seagate Drive: 13 minutes. On this drive? 1.5 hours.Get the Back Up Plus instead. I just wish the item description of this product included writing speeds. It just says "Fast Transfers"
title: EXTREMELY SLOW WRITING SPEED

author: Jeffery P.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2018
review_content: Like many PS4 users whenever I got a new game I would have to delete an old one. I bought this hard drive so that I could expand my storage from 500GB to 2.5TB and that problem has gone away!THE SET UPThe set up was SUPER simple. I plugged in the hard drive with the included cable and my Playstation instantly recognized it. It walked me through the steps to format it and within 5 minutes I was ready to go.USAGEAgain, this was very simple. I started reinstalling some of my old games and the Playstation knew to put them onto the expanded memory as the system's memory was full. It is easy to move the files around between the PS4 and hard drive if need be.PLAYING GAMES OFF THE DRIVEI can tell no noticeable difference when playing the games from the hard drive. There are no noticeable glitches or slowdown in play. All the games work perfectly.I would definitely recommended this hard drive! Especially for anyone looking to expand their PS4's storage. It's simple to set up and works like a charm! If I encounter any issues I will update my review.
title: Perfect for PS4 Storage Expansion

author: edstanjr
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2018
review_content: Working great work my XBox One
title: Awesome

author: Joker Fleck
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2018
review_content: An absolute great purchase! Small and fits in my hand and it doesn’t get in the way! I love that I can buy/download as many PS4 games as my heart desires and it’ll be a long while before the space is filled up!
title: Good

author: Henzo Broquee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2018
review_content: could not pass up - one day sale was 40 bucks off the usual price.deleted factory partitions and formatted as 1 ext4 partition (about 7-odd TB, as expected) for use with my media server. seems to work decently so far. mfgr warranty is only 1 year for US I believe. Amazon offers 30 day free return if defective.some specs:internal HD model: ST8000DM004-2CX188Seagate 8TB Barracuda SATA 6Gb/s 256MB Cache 3.5-Inch 5400rpmSMR / Shingled Magnetic Recording (not the best scheme, but not terrible if you're mostly archiving media / playing back, but not deleting stuff all the time)external model, i.e. this USB3 desktop product as sold by Amazon:STGY8000400 / 763649127322 / 3660619403899 / 10763649127329Made in Thailand (or at least the case + assembly is, not positive about the HD itself, but probably that as well)in addition to the USB3 cable, it came with 6 (yes, six!) country adapters for the (international*) DC brick:- US/CAN - type A- UL/JP - type A- KR - type F- AU - type I- UK - type G- EU - type ?C?not much else to say, for now. it works, quality seems ok. no firmware updates available/visible on Seagate's site.* AC/DC brickinput: 100-240V - 50/60Hz, max 7Aoutput: 12V, 1.5A (i.e. 18W)
title: nice 8TB, esp the sale price; internal 3.5" HD is a decent one.

author: Silent til I speak
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2018
review_content: I am again impressed how technology has advanced. My old hard drive is 4 times as big and probably 8 times as heavy with half the storage... Bought for a Mac, works just fine.
title: It's so tiny!

author: CLAUDIO
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2018
review_content: Very nice!
title: Works well with xbox

author: Cameron S
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2018
review_content: I needed more storage space as I'm a music producer and was running out of storage space on my older 1tb USB 3.0 external drive. So far this drive is working great on my mac and windows machines. No issues of any kind. Hopefully it stays that way.Two points of contention for me are as follows:1. It is a bit noisy when it's running. I've had other drives that were certainly quieter when in use.2. The case seems okay but I wish it were more durable. That being said, for the money, I'd buy it again and I may buy another one to backup my backup because you can't be too careful!
title: Good choice.

author: Orlando
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2018
review_content: 3+ days after beginning a copy of my Time Machine backup (approx. 2 TB), it had yet to complete the copy. It was reading "2 hours remaining" when the copy ultimately failed. I restarted immediately, and here I am 7+ days after it all began and it's stating "2 days remaining."Incidentally, this new drive was purchased to replace a different drive that was dropped from the rotation after it catastrophically failed losing all data. That drive was a Seagate.So disappointed.
title: Absurdly slow write times

author: Eric
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2019
review_content: Got my first unit on Saturday. Would not work out of the box. Would not mount on any computer, tried three different computers, three different operating systems, tried different cables, different power supplies. Nothing. Nothing at all. Contacted Amazon and Seagate. Amazon sent me a new hard drive.Seagate wanted to send me a replacement refurbished unit. I had literally never used the hard drive, just took it out of the box and tried to plug it in and it would not work. No computer would recognize it. At one point Windows said there was something plugged into USB, but it was malfunctioning.And for that brick, Seagate wanted to replace it with a refurbished unit that was up their standards of quality.Got the second unit today. Guess what? Same exact problem. It simply does not exist on any computer I tried it on. I switched cables again, tried these cables with other hard drives, tried different USB ports. It all works fine with other hard drives and yet I get TWO hard drives from Seagate in a row and no computer can even see that there is anything there.And yet again, Seagate wanted to send me a refurbished unit because a hard drive I had tried to use for two hours was never working. If I buy a new product, I want a new product that works. If it fails after a few months, then fine, send me a refurbished unit that will work.But when I buy something that is broken out of the box? Don't try to push someone else's broken unit off on to me and tell me you repaired it when you can't even get a brand new, in the box, unit to work from day one.All in all, Amazon has been great. Seagate was beyond useless though.
title: Two units, DOA!

author: L. Richardson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2018
review_content: I was surprised that the description says only shipping to domestic US and yet the package comes with almost every variation of a power adapter. (See images). Take note there are two that look like US power, but only one says it's for US/CN. This doesn't come in Seagate branded packaging. Strangely, it comes in that brown worry free packaging box.Upon connection, you have a total of 7451 Gigs of the drive available to use.
title: What to expect

author: J.Corda
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2018
review_content: I'm surprised by all the positive reviews.  I'm wondering if mine was just defective.  It won't connect through a USB 3.0 hub, a USB 3.0 extension cable, a USB 2 extension cable, or my TV!  It opened up when I connected it directly to my PC, and I could transfer files.  I brought it over to the USB port on my TCL Roku TV and the media app didn't see it.  I have a 32GB USB stick that works fine on the TV.  Useless drive at least in my experience.  Like I said, maybe mine was defective, but it worked on one of the USB ports so... Idk, but not recommended by me.
title: Barely functional

author: Rachel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2018
review_content: I bought this because it was like $2 cheaper than the competition. I buy hard drives every single day for my business and every model except this one has been awesome from seagate to WD to Toshiba and even the "generic" brand. This one said it would take 78 hours to fill 2TB which on every other hard drive Ive used takes between 2-4 hours. As for durability and usability I cannot comment it felt cheap compared to others BUT as soon as I hit the 12 hour mark and it wasn't even a quarter full I packed it back up and returned it. NO THANKS! Ill pay the extra $2
title: The slowest Hard Drive I have ever used! If you have you dont have 3 days to spare filling move on!

author: Keith Stathem
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2018
review_content: Another reviewer opened up this 8TB drive and researched the internal model #, but I couldn't find anything to confirm that there's no hardware encryption (so the data can be recovered if the usb adapter poops out). So I stuck a few files on it - didn't test the speed, but 390MB took about 2 seconds - then opened it up very carefully (still broke the two smallest tabs in the corners farthest from the connections) then plugged in a SATA cable, and it worked just fine.
title: looks like a decent backup drive

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2019
review_content: A hard drive has one job, and this one fails miserably way too often. I had my entire library of PS4 games on this HD, and it crashed and erased all of my files 4 times. I bought this 4 months ago - so it crashes once a month. I re-download my games on it and it crashes after a few weeks. It is incredibly frustrating every time it happens. Do not buy this under any kind of circumstance, unless you like having all your data deleted over.. and over.. and over.. and over again!
title: This crappy device crashed & deleted all my files 4 times

author: Desmo Due
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2018
review_content: And Seagate is one of the top performers, outperforming WD by a long shot. Don't waste your money on WD.Before you purchase an internal or external hard drive, make sure you buy the best. Google "hard drives with lowest failure rate" and make sure an actual study and its information is provided as proof of which drives have the lowest failure rate.SSD drives are becoming cheaper, but if they're not written onto for a long period of time, they can lose their data. I'm unsure how common that is, but SSD is nice because there are no mechanical parts for failure and truly shock resistant.
title: Research shows 4TB and 8TB External HDD Last The Longest

author: Scott
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2019
review_content: I ordered this Seagate Portable 1TB External Hard Drive HDD - USB 3.0, from Amazon Prime.  The price was good and the drive came the same day.  I connected the hard drive to our iMac 27", which recognized it with no problems.What I did not like was the Seagate Mac registration software (also has the same for Windows) on the hard drive.  I did not like that to be able to use the hard drive you have to register it and agree to their terms and conditions.  I have owned many hard drive over the years (some made by Seagate) and this is the first one that tried to force me to register it, and wanted me to agree to their terms before I could use it. I used the Mac Disk Utility to erase the Seagate portable hard drive and then I used First Aid to repair it, I can now use it like I have used every other hard drive I have ever owned. I have also recently purchased a 1-TB Seagate external SSD hard drive and it did not try to force me to register it to be able to use it.I do not mind registering my hard drives, but I do not like being forced to do it, and I really do not like being forced to agree to their terms!  I am purchasing a BLANK storage hard drive not software.  If this is what Seagate is going to start doing on all it's hard drives, I will start buying other brands, there are plenty of excellent hard drives out there to choose from.
title: Unsatisfied with Seagate forced hard drive registration

author: n/a
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2018
review_content: just use for storage only , can not play media when plug to TV like the others portable do . Disapointed!
title: n/a

author: awesome
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2018
review_content: So i use this to hold most of my steam games but right out of the box trying install games is a huge hassle it takes forever to write downloading is completely fine the speeds are just super slow would not recommend for games or any file transfer!
title: Super slow speeds

author: Sean Bishop
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2019
review_content: It came in the mail, I plugged it in, and it works fine. Writing speed is decent, it barely makes any noise, and it's easy to transport.I've read a lot of other reviews on here and I think they were doing something wrong. One guy stated that it took an hour and a half to move 80 gb, but for me it took an hour and fifteen minutes to move 160 gb. He was probably using a USB 2.0 port, which transfers data slower. Make sure the port your using is actually a USB 3.0 port. My laptop, for instance, has two 3.0 ports on the left and one 2.0 port on the right. Another thing that effects write speed is the amount of files. Moving a single 5 gb file will be faster than moving a 5 gb folder with 200 files in it. The reason is that the computer has to take a microsecond in between each moved file to change files. Also, this hard drive takes a few seonds to spin up if left inactive for too long. Keep that in mind as well.
title: Works perfectly and as intended.

author: KK714
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2019
review_content: It doesn’t work! I transferred about half of the pictures and files that I wanted to but after I did the hard drive corrupted them. (Luckily I hadn’t deleted anything on my computer yet until I was sure the backup worked) I don’t know what happened and I’ve tried turning everything back on and off. I will not send the product back because I cannot delete everything on it but I will be requesting a refund or a new product. I will update after this is settled.**update: the company handled this wonderfully and sent me a new product that worked seamlessly. They did not ask for the old product back and were understanding that it had personal information on it. The new product did exactly what it was supposed to do and I have not experienced any problems with it. (Dec 12, 2019)
title: Buyer beware before you delete original files! (UPDATED)

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2019
review_content: Some other reviewers had reported sustained write speeds in the low double digit MB/s, and I bought it anyway because it was an 'Amazon's choice'. The actual sustained write speed I am getting in about 48 hours of sustained full backup is about 3 MB/s. This device is all but useless for taking full backups, but it may be usable for taking incremental backups (which is why I am not giving it one star). The USB-3 interface is misleading. A USB-2 is many times faster than the speed of the underlying disk itself. It may also me useful for 'big data' type application where data is written once and read many times. I bought it for taking backups.Edit: Device died (not responding to any standard Linux utilities such as 'disks' or 'gparted' after 48 hours of sustained writes (at an avg speed of ~3MB/s). Returning to Amazon for money back.
title: Useless

author: Ray Ruckus
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2019
review_content: When i first took it out of the box, i had nothing but problems with moving files.  The performance was just as the negative reviews state.  And ultimately the drive would become unrecognizable to my laptop.  Then i went through the unplug and plug back in off the USB cable for about the fifth time and started looking at the files that are preloaded on the drive.  The file that mentions Windows Start Here pertained to my system, so I double clicked on it.  Off course it didn't work.  Forgetting all the iterations it took, here is what worked.  I disconnected from the internet, then I plugged in the drive USB cable to my laptop, and once the drive was recognized I connected to the internet.  At this point i double clicked the file again and it loaded a Seagate drive registration page.  I filled in the minimum amount of info and clicked register.  I did nothing else but press finish, which incidentally appeared to do nothing, and didn't close the page.  After manually closing the page, i tried copying files again.  What a difference.  From my E drive i had speeds from 75 to 105Mbs, and com my C drive speeds from 150 to 195Mbs.  My C drive is a solid state 500Th drive, my E drive is 1.5Th internal, and I have 32Th of RAM.  I hope this helps someone.  I was almost to the point of sending this thing back.  Why should i have to register a drive online (with my email address) before being able to use it?  Not sure if i would buy this again, because i don't agree with this policy.  But the drive is now performing as it should.
title: Must Read

author: Amy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2019
review_content: There's something wrong with these drives. I transferred 1TB of data to the drive with no issue, then after a month (also Amazon's return period), write speed slowed to 1kB per second and the drive became unstable, refused to mount under Linux or Windows. I opened an RMA request with Seagate but now I have to spend my own money to ship them back this defective unit to get a "factory repaired" drive back. Not happy: I paid for a new drive and instead, I'm spending extra money and time to get a refurbished drive back. (Which might have the same issue as this one.) Not going to rely on this drive for anything.After some tweaking, I was able to mount the drive & started a format: 14hours later, the first low-level pass over 5TB is still going...Update 1: after a full low-level reformat that took 20hrs to complete, the drive was restored to normal writing speeds. It mounts properly and is working normally. Not sure what happened with the drive controller but I'm worried this issue will repeat itself in the future. Seagate was happy to cancel my RMA.Update 2: after normal operation for a week, the drive now refuses to mount. There's something seriously wrong with this drive.
title: Buyer's Regret

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2020
review_content: I’ve read reviews saying not for Mac but discovered that you need to format it to work with MacOS. When registering the product it will give you instructions to reformat the drive for a Mac Computer. These instructions are for older MacOS. At the top of the instructions it will say for MacOS High Sierra or later click here. After clicking the link the instructions will work perfectly and the HDD will operate as stated. All the formatting is done through DiscUtilities but the instructions tell you what to click on so no worries. Hope this helps someone trying to format the HDD to MacOS. As for performance I just got this drive and have moved one file onto it and it wrote the file very quickly to the drive. Now this is not advising that the drive will last or work for everyone but only my experience of ownership for one day. So far so good and if this HDD fails me I will update the review.UPDATE: June 23, 2020  I have used this now for four months and the hard drive has yet to fail me.  I purchased this to store video files for school and for youtube. I do use thumb drives for a backup and found that the Seagate HDD actually writers faster than my SanDisk thumb drives write. My wife was impressed with this 1 TB drive and I ordered her one not long after and it too is still in use and working perfectly. She also uses a Mac. As from my personal experience I would recommend this SeaGate 1 TB to anyone looking to free up space on their Macs or Windows PCs.
title: Need To Format To MacOS

author: R  Eaton
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2019
review_content: Cheap external hard drive best suited strictly for back up media such as videos, music, and photos. Very, very slow write speeds. My music library transferred at an average speed of 15MB/s (even plugged into a USB 3.0 port). Seeing as this drive didn't cost much I didn't expect much.It does just what I need it to which is back up files. I wouldn't use it to run programs and I cant say I would trust my data on it if I didn't have another back up. The build quality feels cheap as well but again the cost reflects that.Don't set your standards high for this one and you should be fine. Will update if drive happens to fail...EDIT- Correction: Slow write speeds occur only when copying many smaller files which isn't necessarily the drive's fault. When it comes to larger video files, I was getting write speeds of 100+MB/s. Added an extra star for this. If the drive proves reliable long term, this is easily a 5-star drive for the price.
title: Budget HDD.

author: D. Forrester
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2019
review_content: I bought two of these (4TB for myself and 2TB for a friend).  The one lasted all of three weeks.  After Amazon and SEAGATE both tried to troubleshoot it, I was told it could 'lock' itself if you remove the cable at the wrong time.  Seagate did authorize a refund for the one that stopped working, but I asked if it would be better to purchase the model with the external power supply.  I was told 'yes'.  So I will purchase another one.  However, you can't return the 2TB unit with a totally damaged unit.  So I now have to warn my friend to be EXTREMELY careful about how he might disconnect the power cable when the unit is running.  Seems like a flaw in the design to me.  Having learned this, I should just be able to exchange for something with the external power.  Warning to anyone purchasing.  Look for the external power.  It apparently reduces the odds considerably of this being a way to accidentally 'lock' your drive (rendering it disfunctional).
title: doesn't have external power supply which apparently causes the device to lock and not function

author: BEMCEO
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2018
review_content: After Warranty Registration utilizing SERIAL NUMBER, STGY8000400 DOES NOT EXIST ON SEAGATE SUPPORT SITE!
title: After Warranty Registration utilizing SERIAL NUMBER

author: Jordan Williams
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2019
review_content: Overall I like Seagates external hard drives.  Even though this is my 3rd one in 3 years...  The storage capacity, and portability are their biggest pros.  However there could be a lot done to the device to make it better.  First off you have to be very careful when handling this device, one drop, or it hitting something in your bag during transport, can, and more than likely will cause irreparable damage.  I have gone through three because of this.  The first one dropped less than a foot, hit the carpet, and quit working.  The second one hit my laptop while I was driving home, and quit working.  The third one I didn’t drop at all, and it randomly quit after 5 months.  Luckily they’re good about their warranties, even though the application on the website is a humongous pain in the ass.  I had to restart it over 5 different times because it would randomly take me back to the home page, and you couldn’t read or click on half of the parts.  Needless to say after 3 hours of trying, I stopped and contacted them over the phone.  The person who helped me was extremely nice, and apologized about the technical issues on the site.  The second thing they could work on to make it better would be to work on the heat issue, this device gets extremely hot after using it for hours.  Lastly they could make, or purchase a better usb2.0/3.0 cord; the ones they give you are absolute crap.  They last for a few months, 6 at most before they stop working.  My guess is it’s a cheap product purchased in bulk.  If Seagate would take the time to fix these issues, I believe they would have the best EHDs on the market.  Only because of the portability, storage capacity, and customer service do I give this product 3 stars.  Without those three things, I’d advise people not to buy them.  However I do warn people to proceed with caution, and be extremely careful when using one.
title: Be extremely careful with this device

author: kol
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2020
review_content: I plugged the external hard drive into my MacBook Pro. At first the computer recognized it but then said it could not use the drive. I went to Support  on the Amazon order page and asked for help. Amazon called me within 10 seconds. I explained the situation and they put me on hold. A couple of minutes later I was on the line with Apple Support. The Apple tech logged in remotely and fixed my issue. I hung up with Apple with everything fixed. Then about 10 seconds later Amazon called again and asked if the issue had been resolved.Yes, I think this is the most amazing customer service I have ever had on anything anywhere in my 65 year life.As far as the Seagate drive is concerned, it seems fine. It is small for a 4TB drive. It is backing up my laptop as I write this.Thanks Amazon for this amazing customer service.
title: Amazing customer service

author: Terry R. Nye
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2018
review_content: This is my second Seagate portable USB hard drive.  The other one, a 1 TB drive, just wasn't big enough for repeated backups of my computer.  But this 4 TB drive has lots of room and works great.  It was already formatted to work with my Windows 10 computer.  All I had to do was just plug it in to the USB port.  There are no software utilities installed on this drive, but if you register it on the Seagate web site they allow you to download some handy utilities to use with your new drive, including a freeware lite version of Acronis True Image backup software (you also get a discount if you decide to purchase the full version).  I use Acronis True Image to do regular backups, and this drive offers plenty of space for them.  I’ve been using the drive for a while now, and so far I have not incurred any problems with it.  It was well worth its purchase.
title: works great
verified: plenty of room for regular backups

author: Drlulu
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2019
review_content: Purchased on May 18, 2019 - computer will not recognize the device on September 25, 2019...four months of average use, device less than 3TB full, failed for no reason (no bumps, no transport, no drops, no power surge, etc.). Checked all usb ports, tried different cables...still gets error 43 (unrecognized device that malfunctioned). Contacted Seagate technical support - very quick to provide a send off service to recover the drive and replace with another drive...seems Seagate is aware of a possible flaw in this device - seems very suspicious to trade out for another drive with very few technical support steps and troubleshooting steps.Would I buy this product again? NO - should I have bought this product in the first place after reading the reviews about it possibly crashing for no reason - NO. My fault for taking a risk...I hope you don't experience the same result I did.
title: Seems Seagate is aware this device is faulty - 4 Months Crashed with Normal Usage

author: Katie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2019
review_content: My parents have never ever backed up anything ever. Like ever. I finally got them to start backing up photos and their phones to cloud storage but then they get confused and turn everything off on their phones. They aren’t that old and they aren’t senile...they just...click on everything when they can’t figure it out then accuse me of messing up their phones and I fix it again, set everything to backup again and then they remember I sent it up before and say sorry for turning it off and forgetting I sent it up. Then we repeat every few months. They called and were worried about how they were moving and had used their local cable provider email for years and never saved important documents, photos or emails anywhere but kept them sitting in the email account which they are about to lose access to when they move and discontinue the local internet provider. Yes I have set up gmail accounts which they promptly forget about and don’t use and yes I write it all down for them and again they aren’t that old. So I jumped on amazon and ordered this external hard drive, the 1 TB storage.It’s small and light. Comes with a cord and starts right up when plugged in. There is an option to set it up to secure files. It took like 20 seconds to register the device and it also has the option to format for Mac or Windows computers.I moved a bunch of photos and videos over and saved them on the external hard drive. I worked exactly like it was supposed to and I was able to show my dad how to access the files and add more files create folders etc. I was happy with how quickly it started up (I’ve had some previously that had a little delay) because my parents would immediately jump to it being broken. It’s easy to use, saves quickly and does exactly what I needed for a very reasonable price.
title: Does exactly what it says supposed to do and ready to go outside of the box

author: Greg Miller
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2019
review_content: Get ready for a sad Seagate hard drive story.The Bottom line: Brand new drive was defective (it quit in the middle of copying with plenty of storage capacity still remaining) and I wanted to return it, but I could not empty the trash (that's just one of the defects).The blow-by-blow: I got the Seagate external 1TB Drive and started backing up files from my Macbook (os 10.6.8). Several files and folders copied at a reasonable speed and appeared intact on the Seagate, but In the middle of backing up my next set of files, the operation quit and I got an error message; I believe it was  "The operation can't be completed because an unexpected error occurred (error code -1407)"The file appeared grayed out and inaccessible on the Seagate drive, obviously having only partially transferred, so I threw the grayed out folder in the Trash and tried again. Same thing.The Seagate Drive displayed the files I had successfully copied, which totaled appx 300GB, but the Drive then said it was completely full and had 0kb available. Weird.I shut down and restarted the computer.The drive then appeared normally on the desktop, displaying the files I had copied intact and 600+ GB available on the drive.I tried copying another folder. It quit in the middle and I got another error message. I think this one was "The operation can't be completed because an unexpected error occurred (error code -51)"Now having lost all confidence in this drive as a reliable backup, and preparing to return it, I threw all my files in the Trash and tried to empty the trash but, after HOURS of watching the computer prepare to empty the trash of 100,000 items, then, finally, ever so slowly, start to delete those items at the rate of about one item one every 3-5 minutes (estimated time remaining 48 hours, that kind of pace), the computer eventually quit and gave me another error message. I think that one was  "The operation can't be completed because an unexpected error occurred (error code -8003)". I tried Empty Trash and Secure Empty Trash. Same thing.Incredibly frustrating – and time consuming!I can open the Trash and see my files there, some of them grayed-out, but I can not empty it. The files include original copyrighted content files, my System Folder and Library Folder, which contain Keychains and other sensitive information.Amazon chat support was helpful and is crediting me for the item, but I will be trying a different brand next.BTW, the Seagate was meant to replace a Toshiba external drive which suddenly died on me.I don't understand why this technology seems so hard to perfect.
title: Don't

author: Andrew R. Alberts
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2018
review_content: So I bought this to backup my PLEX server to and about 500GB of files took almost 11 Hours to transfer. Now, I knew that going into this (I read the reviews first) but I have an old school (4 years old now) WD 5400rpm hard drive that transfers at average of 38.8 MB/s. This Drive only transfers at 19.4 MB/s Average. That's pretty sad. Deducted a star for poor write performance. That being said, everything else has been fine. Worked great out of the box, installation was super simply (ie plug in the drive). And for the price? Well I call it a good value. Just know what you are buying.
title: Slow Slow Slow!!!

author: LJ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2020
review_content: My 16TB model came with an Exos X16 inside. The performance of the hard drive was great as expected with a 16TB Exos X16.
title: 16TB contains an Exos X16

author: Brett G.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2020
review_content: Here's a picture of this drive playing a 4K video via USB 3.0 on my Mac.  Yes, I have the TerraMaster RAID drive, but the 4K video in the picture is playing from the Seagate drive, not the TerraMaster.  I mostly use this Seagate drive (STGY8000400) as a backup drive, and I have had no issues with it so far for a year (knock on wood).  I'm about to order a second one because I need more backup space (I shoot and edit 4K video).  You can see it's very low on space, so it's time for me to add a clean drive.Formatting for a Mac is easy.  Step 1, ignore the software that comes with the drive.  It's useless.  Instead, open Disk Utility, connect the drive, and use Disk Utility to format the drive to HFS+.  The drive will be fine without the bloatware that comes with it.  Now, it will just act like a hard drive.By the way, most external hard drives are Mac compatible if they are formatted properly the first time they are connected.  The NTFS for Mac software is only required if one intends to use a drive to transfer files between Mac and Windows.I'm using Carbon Copy Cloner as my backup software, instead of Apple's Time Machine.  Once Time Machine fills up, it stops backing up, and it's a pain to delete old items.  I find CCC to be much faster and much more stable, and it gives me better warnings when it encounters trouble.  I'm also using Backblaze as a secondary off-site backup.  2 is 1 and 1 is none.As far as sending files to it, I don't have problems with the transfer speed.  For anyone having trouble, I'd recommend checking the cabling first and foremost to make sure both the power supply and the USB 3.0 cable are the proper ones, and then listening to the drive for the dreaded "click of death."  If you have the "click of death," let Seagate know and get a replacement.  In my experience, dead drives are a plague of Seagate.  I've had a few in the past.  So far, this one has been good.
title: Works just fine on my Mac

author: Bill
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2018
review_content: Ok RV'S  looking for and external hard drive for their  Dish TV Wally (THIS IS IT)!!  This external hard drive does work on your Dish Wally.  I purchased this drive just for this purpose.  Easy to install, once install took Dish 1 minute to activate.One note on installation, there are 2 USB port on the back of your Wally. One USB 2.0 and one USB 3.0. You must connect to the correct USB port. You must connect to the USB 3.0 port. Unfortunately they are not labeled.  The Wally will read the drive on both port and will activate the external drive on both port. But will only record on the USB 3.0 port.  So if it doesn't record after activating change to the other USB port on the Wally.
title: Dish TV  Wally external hard drive

author: Master of Cats
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2019
review_content: Incredibly slow. Slower than USB 2 and this claims it's USB 3. And I was using the included cable and a fast USB 3 port in my computer that has done lightning fast USB 3 transfers before.Listing doesn't show write speeds and read speeds, just says ""Fast Transfers" and I trusted it because it was a Seagate drive.Speeds are NOWHERE NEAR the claimed  "5.0 Gbps (USB 3.0)."Reading the one star reviews now I see I'm not the only one.Note to self: always read the one-star reviews.
title: Slow slow slow slow transfers. I am returning this.

author: Satisfied
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2019
review_content: I ordered this item and after 2 weeks no computer could recognize the hard drive. It made a weird sound on every computer I tried it on and I tried it in multiple computers. It was defective. I hate to have anyone go through what I went through. I lost a lot of data on it. Lots of work hours! I could not send it back because I could not get any computer to recognize it in order to wipe it clean of my data, thus risking a breach in personal and work information. I lost a lot of time I devoted to my work, compromised multiple computers, and did not receive a full refund from Amazon for the principal of the thing. It wasn't just the hard drive I lost. I have been a long-standing Amazon Prime customer so this is very unsettling. I would never order technology from Amazon again. I have never had difficulty through Staples and other places and have purchased may portable hard drives because I need them often.  This is really a bad move to order this through Amazon.
title: DO NOT ORDER THIS ITEM OR ANY TECHNOLOGY FROM AMAZON

author: Dennis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2020
review_content: So, after my 3rd 8TB Seagate Expansion drive failed I started to get suspicious and I did some research on what exactly was going on with these drives.  Obviously the price was right for the amount of storage capacity and with the way technology moves, I didn't think much about the lower price, chalking it up to how the world of technology evolves and gets cheaper over time.  This assumption came at a cost.  After researching and shucking one of the drives that failed (conveniently for Seagate,  outside the 1-year warranty) I discovered that the drives they are throwing in the external shells are regular Barracudas.  Nothing to cause alarm yet, Barracudas are supposed to be good reliable drives right?  Digging a little deeper, I discover that Seagate, Western Digital and pretty much every other drive manufacturers are starting to use SMR (Shingled Magnetic Recording) technology on their cheaper consumer drives, making the price more feasible for a greater number of consumers.  The problem is, these drives are only really good for archival purposes, meaning, you should really only write files to the drive once, never deleting, moving, or re-writing files without major stability issues due to the nature of the way this drive writes data.  There are plenty of articles about SMR technology if you google "SMR drive" so I won't go into too technical of a description of how that works, but basically for me, who was expecting to be able to use this drive as I have every other drive I've owned for the last 35+ years, I was sadly mistaken.  The act of moving files or deleting and rewriting information seemed to be such a routine and mundane task that I never would imagine that kind of action would contribute to the premature death of 3 of these drives.
title: 3 drives have failed in less that 2 years.  Cheap SMR drive inside.  Not designed for "normal" use.

author: JB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2019
review_content: After yet another WD drive failure, figured I'd try a Seagate.  Within two months began getting errors.  Did a repair, and seemed good another three months.  Seven months in, after a repair and then a reformat, the thing keeps unmounting itself during data transfers.  Definitely will be my last Seagate.
title: Drive giving errors in two months

author: Thomas Porter
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2020
review_content: I bought this drive to add more storage to my PS4Pro.  In the pictures I thought this thing was going to be near the size of my PS4.  Its not.  It's about the size of my hand.  I see pictures in the other reviews.  I had to find the power adapter for the USA in their many adapters included with this.  I put that onto the power adapter and plugged it in and hooked the cord to the front of the PlayStation.  Does not seem to work with the plug on the back of the PlayStation.  I would prefer that to keep the cords out of sight.  Anyway went into set up and selected to format it for extended storage.  took around 60 seconds.  Then it was ready to use.  I moved a few older games off of my hard drive that I don't play much.  Then I reinstalled all of the games I still enjoy playing but do not play everyday.  I tried out a couple of those.  Red Dead Redemption 2, which I am hopelessly stuck in.  And Witcher 3.  Both played with out any noticeable longer load times or any problems playing.  It still takes around an hour per game to install.  But that was the same with the internal hard drive for PS4.  Anyway I am very pleased.  If I have any problems I will come and update my review.
title: Small and quiet drive.  Great for PS4

author: TK
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2019
review_content: For the money, this is a great buy for 5TB, but the advertised data transfer speed 120 MB/s is not even close. I bench-marked this drive with Aja System Test and the transfer rate is 37 MB/s Writing and 38 MB/s Reading. I then benchmarked my 4TB Western Digital My Passport Ultra USB-C ready, USB 3.0 compatible and the data transfer rates are 114 MB/s Writing and 116 MB/s Reading. It’s a no brainer that the Seagate drive is slow as a snail.If you are not concerned about data transfer rates, the Seagate 5TB is great buy for the money. However, if you’re concerned about data transfer rates, then go with the Western Digital My Passport Ultra USB-C ready, USB 3.0 compatible.WARRANTYSeagate offers 1 Year Limited Warranty.Western Digital offers 3 Years Limited Warranty.CONCLUSIONSeagate loses because the data transfer rate is nowhere close to what is advertised and also the short 1 Year warranty. Western Digital wins because of the faster data transfer rates and better 3 Year warranty.
title: Great Capacity For The Money, But Slow As A Snail

author: Willy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2019
review_content: I already had a similar Seagate external HD connected to my new X-Box One X, and after downloading the two "free" games offered for being a Live Gold member, I saw that drive's % going down at an alarming rate.So, I went looking for another USB 3.0 external HD, being partial to the previous Seagate I have had for multiple years, I settled on this drive.X-Box One recognized it as soon as I plug it in and formatted it in seconds. I was able to move several games from the other Seagate to this new drive in a matter of minutes. It took 30 minutes, at the most, to move two large games (Hitman + 6 or 7 DLCs and Forza 6) from the first drive to the second drive, so the USB 3.0 is fast and efficient.It's nice to see on the bottom of the X-Box One screen that I'm at 4% with 8.5 TB free.
title: Good Drive, Got it to use with my X-Box One X

author: gerald n
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2020
review_content: First off, I really dislike how amazon allows for reviews for ~17 different products to all live mixed together under the same rating.  These are not just tiny variations on the same product either.I just bought 2 of the 5TB portable drives.  They look identical.  The model number is identical.  The drives inside are most certainly NOT.  One of my drives writes and reads at over 100mb/sec (~115).  As expected.  The other drive, it reads at 85 mb/sec and only writes at 15mb/sec. (!) Not just in bench marks.  When actually moving many TBs of large files.  One one drive, it took 2 days.  The other drive, same data, ~8 hours.  I guarantee if I were to open them both up, they would be entirely different 2.5" drives inside.  The slow one also makes more noise and vibrates more.  It seems to function properly, and basically runs like a 10 year old laptop drive.  But it can't possibly be the same hardware in there considering the other one is so much faster.  Just transferring the exact same large file, from one drive to the other, then back again, it's completely obvious we aren't dealing with identical drives, not even close.  The write speed is literally 6x faster on the normal one.  Read speed is also better. Seriously, Seagate?4-5 stars if I all I got was the normal working one.  That one is great.  It's identical brother though?  That drive is not great and it makes me leery to buy any portable devices from Seagate again.  (I own 4)Spread out your reviews, Seagate.  And fix the QA.
title: 2 identical drives that were not even close to the same

author: Dean Farrell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2019
review_content: Now this is standard in the industry, so it's not just this drive.  Bought 8TB drive.  Empty space as delivered 7.26 TB.  Now I knew there would be file system overhead, but how about putting that in the spec. And I know it will be the same on other drives, it's just annoying.This drive is slow.  I get write speeds of 23-25mb/s .  Other drives connected on the same port get up 190mb/s.  Not sure why this drive is so slow.  But it think it is actually as USB 2.0 drive, even though it use a 3.0 cable.  Performance does not match specifications.  Spent over 2 days copying 3.4 terabytes to this drive.  Copied to another model seagate and it ran in hours.Will see how reliable it is.  Too new to tell at this point.
title: SLOW SPECS LIE = Claims 160MBS, ONLY GETS 25MBS

author: ighost
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2020
review_content: Starting from the package, this product looked fishy, if you are buying hard drives you know what I am talking about. It's not the package normal hard drive from respectful company comes with. Yes, also inside the plastic insert was damaged, like it's not new or fake product. But later on I discovered that many reviews for this product say it's incredibly SLOW. Meaning i put some backup to copy (about 1TB) and it it usually takes about 2 hours, but I noticed the slowness, so I left it overnight and when I woke up in the morning there was about 50% of that copied...The second part is Amazon support (I didn't expect such a lousy treatment, especially after I was contact by "executive" support. They offered me to return it, that was not an issue. But seriously? I copied about 500GB of my data so far. I work in IT all my entire life I know how easily the data can be recovered when it's deleted or even after formatting even without any special equipment. I expressed my concern to Amazon support, stating that I use to destroy my hard drives before I throw it out and somehow all that I was answered by first level support but also by executive representative after that, that if I return damaged or destroyed product they won't refund me or charge me a fee??? Hello? Have I ever said I will damage or destroy the product before the return?All I meant, are you going to compensate me with any damages I may incur if any part of the info that I put in that drive so far ever comes up online or anywhere??? Are you going to ask to return worn underwear as well??? I guess ~$100 loss is not very pleasant, but it's not worth the risk of any potential data exposure.PRODUCT - ZERO starsSupport - ZERO stars
title: Complete garbage, it deserves ZERO points

author: Alex Rogers
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2020
review_content: I have learned over the years that (small, portable) external hard drives are not particularly trustworthy, and most of them last at most a couple of years before they stop being readable. For that reason I always keep two permanently connected to my computer, each running a sequential backup every hour or so.I know that sooner or later I'll have to replace one, but I feel fairly confident that the second one will continue to work at least until I get the replacement.This particular Seagate drive, however, was doubtlessly the worst so far, as it lasted less than three months.To add insult to the injury, I found out that Seagate's first-level support is abysmally incompetent.The first technician that responded informed me, quite cheerfully, that they'd make sure to make me very satisfied, although no, they would not replace the unit because they did not ship to Puerto Rico.On strongly worded WTF-get-me-your-manager later, I was told that of course they would ship me a replacement, and gave me the instructions to request an RMA online.The only form, again, did not accept addresses from Puerto Rico, so more communications time had to be wasted so that the second-level technician force-entered the address into their returns system.I was also cheerfully informed that all replacements are refurbished units.Lastly, while I was in the process of sending the drive back to Seagate for replacement, I was sent another message cheerfully informing me that my case was being closed due to "lack of response".Another WTF message was required to receive a last cheerful "clarification" that what they meant was that because the replacement was already being processed, they would proceed to close the support ticket.I did get the replacement unit, and it does appear to be working, but I have only had it running a couple of weeks. We shall see.If it's within my power and I can help it, however, I will definitely avoid getting another Seagate drive ever.
title: Unreliable

author: Joshua
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2020
review_content: **WARNING THIS WILL VOID YOUR WARRANTY**I was looking for a few drives to add capacity to my NAS, with all the articles out about SMR and all the issues it causes with ZFS, I did som research. It looked like all of Seagates 10tb drives were CMR (which is a good thing). I rolled the door e and bought two.The case was super easy to remove, no glue holding stuff together, just a piece of aluminum tape. Inside was a Barracuda Compute Pro (as expected). Removed the USB3 interface, and popped them in my NAS. They spun right up, and easily added to my pool. Haven’t had a problem since.Keep in mind below the 10tb Seagate does use SMR (really meant for archives, so ideal for a backup drive) this will cause slow write times. At the time of writing this, all of Seagates 10tb+ drives are CMR and do not suffer the drawbacks of SMR.
title: Great for shucking/ZFS NAS

author: Saveyourmoney
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2020
review_content: I'm not an expert at computers. I DO KNOW, it is 2020. I read reviews from various sites. We work hard for our money! I demand quality! This is the slowest transfer of files ever. I'm disgusted how there's no mention of this in any of the reviews. I moved simple files, (pictures, movies, downloaded pins, music ect.) was an all day process. With a couple of failures to copy. I had to go over each folder to ensure transfer. These so called "experts" and "power users" have very low standards of quality and durability. Which regardless of brand, averaged 3 years. I only went with this brand because of actual use of other brands, which were let down. I absolutely do not trust Samsung brand. However, due to sheep mentality and no standards, those of us with intelligence  are collateral damage. There's no way files shouldn't transfer in a snap! Self driven cars, facial recognition, mining of data, space programs, and spread of viral diseases, and it takes an hour to tranfer a television series. Make excuses and give justification for your willfull ignorance. I'm not going to lie to win friends, or influence people. This is my experience. Every dollar we have is suffered for. This product is average at best. Good luck.
title: Nothing special. Slow transfer of files.

author: Cliff T. Jones
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2020
review_content: When I bought this backup hard drive, I bought based on the title of the product, which states "for PC Laptop and Mac".  I did not read the reviews until I plugged it into my 2016 MacBook Pro, which has macOS High Sierra 10.13.6.  That is when I learned that it was formatted for PC.  So, I looked up the product that I had ordered on Amazon to make sure it said for Mac. This is when I read multiple reviews stating that it doesn't work for Mac, especially anything later than Mac OS 10.10. I started to freak out internally, but kept my composure and decided to try formatting the drive anyway by following the formatting instructions that Seagate gives you when registering the product. Although the formatting instructions are outdated and say that it's for Mac OS 10.6 to 10.10, they were easy to follow--my 10.13.6 version of disk utility is slightly different than the pictures in the instructions, but it worked...I partitioned the device and reformatted to "Mac OS Extended (Journaled)" just like the instructions said to do. I clicked partition, it took 30 seconds or so, and then it was done. Now the drive works and I can drag and drop files there with ease. I then went back to the Seagate registration page that I left open in my browser, clicked next for "Set up your drive to work with Macs" and the checkbox that was previously empty was now filled with a green check. I'm not sure if the others on here followed instructions (I saw reviews as recent as June 2020 that said it doesn't work for Mac), or if Seagate simply fixed the issues between June 2020 and now (I am writing this review on August 11, 2020). But I can confirm that, for my version of Mac OS, it works. Hope this is helpful so other Mac users don't freak out based on the other reviews.
title: Works for Mac OS High Sierra 10.13.6 - Followed Formatting Instructions

author: Brice A. Mcmillan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2020
review_content: I use this to backup my media. I had heard that the write performance was bad, but this 16TB model performed very well, even 2/3 full. It does get hot when run for long, over 50C. A fan was placed under the drive to get temperature under control. I assume it would power off at 60C. 1 star off for not saving plastic and leaving holes in the top of the enclosure. But it is a good drive. 15 hours to back up 11TB. It even comes with a variety of power adapters for other countries.
title: 16TB of hot CMR

author: Dave
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2020
review_content: when i first got the drive, i plugged it in hoping to back up some critical data.  the drive while hooked into a usb 3.0 slot would heat up almost immediately and begin to throttle transfer speeds down to about 0-3kb/s.  it would start off very fast, and then within a few minutes just completely drop like a lead brick.  hooking it up to usb 2.0 allowed me to transfer data without overheating and throttling transfer speeds, but made backing data up a painfully slow experience, but not as slow as the throttled speeds on usb 3.0.bottom line, look elsewhere.  i have another seagate 2tb external usb 3.0 drive that doesn't suffer from the overheating/throttling problem.  maybe it's just a defective drive, regardless i would advice to look elsewhere for a reliable external data storage and ABSOLUTELY discourage anyone from buying this drive for backing up critical data.  or at least consider redundancy as it seems this drive will probably not live long.
title: overheats on usb 3.0

author: Robert D. Levin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2019
review_content: Below is my original review that I'll leave in case you experience the same issue. The fault was the internal 1TB hard drive in my PC had started running out of space from my documents and photos (I'm a writer and artist) after eight years of use. The solution given the age of my desktop computer was to pay a local young man a very reasonable price to install a new 2TB internal hard drive, which also allowed several Windows 10 updates with the extra space. The PC is now acting like a new computer. Note that he cloned the old hard drive to the new one so there was no need to reload programs; even my briefcase links still worked with the new 2TB hard drive. All of this made the two 4TB Seagate external hard drives work as intended at the time of purchase. I'm very pleased! FYI: In the future when buying a new PC or external hard drive I'm going to make sure they are the more modern "solid state" components.I have two 1TB Seagate external hard drives that usually take around 5 hours to backup all of my documents. This new 4TB Seagate has been downloading 19 hours and is only three quarters of the way finished. I'm not happy and bought two. Why are they so incredibly SLOW? A week later I contacted Seagate support that tried blaming my computer after eliminating all other possibilities. So I'm returning both units and switching to Western Digital. Goodbye Seagate...you have failed my customer loyalty standard since your product does not work as intended at the time of purchase.
title: Rewrote my review, this product works fine...please read.

author: alibel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2019
review_content: EDITED - I did *not* purchase this as an SSD, so the noise is somewhat expected. Still pretty loud in my book. I'll be placing it somewhere farther away from my desk the noise is distracting.Bought this a year ago and just opened it up and plugged it in to use it with my new Mac. I immediately noticed that it makes quite a bit of noise, which is a little annoying since I thought an SSD would be more quiet (see edit - it's not an SSD, oops). I love the amount of space that's on it (8TB!), especially when my old 1TB external was always filling up and Time Machine was giving me "out of space" alerts. I've always purchased Seagate for my backup and external hard drives because they have a great reputation and I've never been let down by one.I'm at this moment waiting for it to do the full, fresh TimeMachine backup, it's a little slow but it's backing up 475GB so I'm expecting a little slowness. Update: it took about 5 hours to do the initial back up. Not a big deal since I set it up and walked away to do other things so it wasn't like I had to wait on it.I'll update if there are any issues or if the noise level of the drive goes down, it's quite annoying. UPDATE: It's very clunky and noisy when kicked on, which happens quite often even through I'm not reading/writing to it other than the hourly TimeMachine backup
title: Works, a bit slow, very noisy

author: D. Gibson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2020
review_content: I formatted it exFAT so I can use on pc and mac, though I use a macbook pro 2017 mostly. And this drive has been a nightmare. If the cord so much as gets bumped (which is often the case), it will come unplugged. You get the little pop up message saying it ejected without doing it officially. Normally, I just plug something back in. But no, not this dude. It's grayed out in DISK UTILITY. I can't mount or unmount it. It won't "eject" through THAT menu. Iiterally have to restart my computer over a dozen times...and try various things such as ... plugging it in first, then restarting. Then trying to wait to plug in until it's restarted. I do a handful of things, different each time, and when i'm about to chuck it, it will suddenly work. I'm so over it. I need to get a new drive now so I can copy everything off of this one (if it ever loads again)...as I'm on restart 14 this time.... the 5th time it's happened in the past month because my cat jumped up to lie down on the warm laptop. I'm over it. The last SeaGate drive I owned just stopped working--i tried everything. And then when I invested another $400 in a diff drive and spent a fortune trying to get all my files downloaded from my off-site server (BackBlaze, which is another cluster F of epic proportions)...after a month of tedious, time-consuming stuff, suddenly, it started working again. WHAT THE??? So back to toshiba or Western Digital I go.
title: Useless if it comes unplugged accidentally

author: Boston Doc
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2019
review_content: The description says this drive is compatible with PC or MAC. I have a 1TB Seagate and love it, so bought this 5TB to get more storage. When connected to a MAC, it warns that it is partitioned for Windows and then gives step by step instructions for how to re-partition it for a MAC. The instructions and screenshots don't match at all what you see when you open disk utility, though, and the operation fails. I tried four times. I then tried a live chat with Amazon tech support, which was not at all helpful. I've returned it and will buy one that I know is MAC compatible as plug and play. This one is certainly not that.
title: Don't buy this if you have a MAC - as far from Plug and Play as you can get

author: Steven Reed
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2019
review_content: I’m using this with my Xbox One S as a media HDD for my movies (I have legally ripped my DVDs and Blurays — about 1,500 movies plus about 15 full TV series — with handbrake and my old 2TB HDD was no longer big enough).The only downside was that, at first, I couldn’t figure out to get my MacBook Pro to “see” all 4TBs. My computer is old enough that it will only recognize 2TB or smaller drives. But after messing around, I was able to format it as ExFAT (I think that’s what I ended up formatting it as), and my computer and Xbox recognized it.So now, it’s about 2.2TB full and is my media drive for movies and tv shows.
title: Great as Media Drive for Xbox

author: Person
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2019
review_content: I'm familiar with this brand– I use a backup drive by them, which worked ok until just a couple weeks prior to my purchasing this external hard drive. It should have removed previous material and updated to the new material on the computer, but stopped removing and wouldn't function. My computer then began giving me warnings that there was not enough space on my hard drive, so I thought I'd read through multiple reviews. Not sure why, but opted to purchase this one due to reviews. Bad idea. It would only allow me to transfer small files. It would freeze my entire computer, forcing me to power it down manually and then boot it up again to get access to my computer again. THEN, I would attempt to transfer the larger files and it would say that it was "estimating time". It would say this for hours. It would stop working if my computer went to sleep. I sat the first time for two hours keeping my computer from sleeping, because it said it would take 2 hours to transfer. 6 hours later, no dice. HUGE waste of money and time. Won't EVER purchase Seagate anything again. No number for customer service/tech support provided in my packaging. Returning it. Don't waste your time. Good reviews must have been purchased or perhaps for PCs?
title: Horrible Horrible Horrible, Especially For MacBook Pro

author: Mike Reddy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2020
review_content: The unit (STGY8000400 purchased April 2020) contains a Seagate Barracuda 8TB 256MB cache model ST8000DM004-2CX188. The SATA/USB controllers on these backup drives are horrible for writing, and its 5400 RPM class drive. Relatively cheap cost, but low throughput. And (at least on my Mac) the controller often causes the OS to hang with a beach ball when the drive powers out of sleep - 30+ seconds a times which is annoying. I try to only leave them connected when in specific use. All of these external USB drives from Seagate and WD are best  for archiving &  backup purposes. Don't expect to run applications off this drive or otherwise use it as a working drive. Buy an external SSD for that or make your own external HDD unit with a USB enclosure and a 7200 RPM drive like the Barracuda Pro or Iron Wolf series - but expect to pay almost triple the cost of this drive for an external 2TB SSD, or over that for an 8TB Pro or Iron Wolf drive plus an enclosure. You get what you pay for in performance. As far as portability goes, I would not recommend traveling further than a few feet with this thing - its not a case made to protect the drive very well in mobile use and its not bus powered. Also its airflow cooled - no fan - and the case is plastic. The Seagate tools for checking physical health are Windows-only which is ridiculous in 2020. Strongly urge using a SMART monitor tool for drives on all platforms because they do wear out, especially in consumer environments without temperature and dust control.
title: Seagate Desktop 8TB - its a Barracuda with a cheap SATA/USB controller

author: Angel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2018
review_content: I have a few Segate external hard drives as well as 3 internal hard drives.  Seagate products have never failed nor crashed on me ever.  I have 2 old Buffalo 500GB external drives with Seagate drives in them.  I bought them in 2007.  I check the health and reliability of all my hard drives once a month or 2 months.  Still healthy and strong.  I use external hard drives for video and photography storage.  Half of my drives are storage and the other half is a redundancy back-up drives for the 1st half.  I do have 1 WD internal hard drive that is coming up bad
title: meaning it can fail at anytime.  So I will be replacing it with a Segate drive soon.

author: Mary Balsorah
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2020
review_content: This portable drive has 5T storage capacity. It will work with Macs and uses Mac's Time Machine application. I had some trouble setting it up on two Mac laptops I own. I called tech support and they are terrific. I had to call several times for different issues on each machine and they were extremely helpful. First, they call you back within a few minutes. They are patient, professional, polite, and extremely knowledgeable about their drive and about the Mac operating system. So, they walked me through very specific steps that I could easily follow and for each issue, they were able to find a solution such that the drive now works on both machines and automatically backs up the system as soon as the drive is plugged in. The cost of the drive is very reasonable for the amount of storage it provides. Although I had to call tech support several times, I'm glad I did and glad to have this external storage for backup.
title: If you want to make a backup you can read years down to the line, use Seagate...

author: Nat B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2020
review_content: I had my 1TB storage for 3 years and couple weeks ago my MacBook was unable to open it and I freaked out because I had all my work and personal memories on it. Let me tell you, their customer service is TOP NOTCH! They recovered my data in 2 weeks for free and for my surprise they sent the data back on a new 4TB storage device!!! I bought this 5TB right after I sent in my old Seagate for recovery, but now I just don't even know what to do with so much storage space! Very happy customer here!! Thank you Seagate!!
title: Best customer service! I'm a Seagate customer for life!

author: F1R35P1N
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2020
review_content: Easy to format for my MacBook Pro. Really. I'm not sure what kind of instructions some customers complained about, but this was basically plug and play, with an innate reformatting at the first startup.Several wall/floor adapters for the power cord so you don't have to scrounge around to fit into your socket.Somewhat noisy, but unless your place is super quiet, it will just blend into the rest of the sounds.Arrived in 4 days!!! I will give it the good ol' 90 day trial run and if anything changes, i'll update this review.
title: Great Value

author: dheche
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2020
review_content: Was trying to register the hard drive but didn't end up doing it because they wanted me to agree to below privacy statement:“Personal Information” is information that identifies you as an individual or relates to an identifiable individual. We collect information through the Sites and Offerings such as:NameSite user namePostal addressTelephone numberEmail addressProfile pictureSocial media account IDIP AddressYour designated account settingsDisclosure of Personal InformationWe disclose Personal Information:To our affiliates including:Seagate Technology LLC – Located in the United StatesSeagate Singapore International Headquarters Pte. Ltd. – Located in SingaporeSeagate Technology (Netherlands) B.V. – Located in the NetherlandsNippon Seagate Inc. – Located in JapanSeagate Cloud Systems, Inc. – Located in the United StatesSeagate Cloud Systems Japan Ltd – Located in JapanSeagate (Hangzhou) Data Recovery Services Co., Ltd – Located in ChinaLaCie SAS – Located in FranceLaCie Ltd - Located in EnglandLaCie Electronique D2, S.A. – Located in Spainfor the purposes described in this Privacy Statement.
title: Buyer be aware! Seagate (Hangzhou) Data Recovery Services Co., Ltd – Located in China

author: JG
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2020
review_content: Without question, this is the loudest external drive I have ever owned. It's so loud, man.You don't want this thing in the room with you if you're trying to watch tv or just straight up have a conversation.You can barely even sleep in the next room without this thing acting up. I had to place this beast on a soft cloth to try to absorb some of the noise.It seems to work fine otherwise, though. It transfers speedily enough. No problems in that regard.But man, this thing is soCRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH!!!!See what I mean?! Even now it's crunching away on...something. I'm not copying or opening or saving or playing or indexing or time-machining or whatever. It just likes to crunch.I'm not even lying. You gotta believe me. This thing is loud.I appreciate the 10TB of space but I wouldn't recommend this drive, and will not be buying another one.To sum up this whole review:CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH!!!!You have been warned.
title: CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH!!!!

author: badley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2020
review_content: Being self-employed for a few years now, my tradition is to get a new external backup drive whenever I get a new business laptop.  That way, I can independently back up and sync back and forth with my old laptop, at least until I'm SURE that the new laptop will work out.  It's also nice to have the old emergency backup laptop and drive in the event something goes horribly wrong.  That is admittedly rare, but I learned the hard way that the extra bucks for an external drive and the habit of backing up my data (daily to a flash drive and weekly to an external hard drive) are definitely worth avoiding the potential for days of business data re-entry.  My laptop internal drive is 1 TB, and this external 5 TB drive is plenty large enough for 1) The built in Windows 10 back-up, 2) the legacy Windows 7 drive image backup, 3) a repository for my media and disk images that would clutter the onboard storage on the laptop, AND 4) an encrypted volume for rapid syncing of my crucial/sensitive data.
title: Great Portable Backup Solution

author: BabyGiant
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2020
review_content: I admit I have 8 of these drives in various capacities... mostly 8TB and a couple of 16TB. We humans can be weird and somehow when shopping, look for any small financial savings without taking our precious time and the content of our data into account.  I am such a person- chose to save money and buy the Seagate. I regret it pretty much every time.On this purchase, I did a 10TB clone from a master drive to this off-site backup. The drive was loud enough that I had to move it to a different room and use a laptop to do the clone. The next morning, the drive was doing a rhythmic click and giving errors. So after about 24 hours of sustained writes, it failed. Amazon replaced it the next day but now I have anxiety each time I use it. So, 2 stars because the cost is right but wow is it worth it? I don't think I'll get Seagates (or Lacie's) ever again. Though every drive can fail, I haven't had any issues yet with my WD desktop units. These are rarely-used backup-only drives but I expect them to at least be able to survive the first copy task.
title: Loud, slow, failed at 24 hours... and for what?

author: XcapeArtix
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2020
review_content: With the price of SSDs with any large capacity being so high, this drive is a budget choice for local storage. It's suitable for storing your data, but I don't recommend using it for anything that requires a lot of access (ie, heavy photo/video editing, daily backups, watching movies).I use it for a semi-production task. It holds photos of 3D scan data for 3D modeling and essentially gets accessed for computation once every 1-2 hours for loading program scene and then building the initial 3D models from the images. After that, the build data is moved to another drive for actual work.I would not use this for any type of full production or any work that requires a lot of constant access to the drive. Could not image trying to do video editing or full 3D work off this drive. It's too slow and has a bit of a warm up spin. I have a 32TB RAID of another brand with physical discs that reads/writes way faster than this drive, yet both have disc that rotate at same speed.I have not had any issues with it disconnecting or losing power. Its black finish and small light indicator are not visual distractions while working. It's relatively quiet when it spins up, but makes a detectable vibration on my desk at start up. This old warm-up spin is annoying in the age of instant access SSDs, but I need to remember to be patient with spinning disc like this.
title: Good for storage drive, not for production work

author: '49 C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2019
review_content: When I connected the drive to my Windows 7 computer, Windows 7 would not recognize it. So I called tech support, and of course a guy from a foreign country, who I could barely understand, and had to ask him numerous times to repeat what he was saying very slowly over and over again, I finally understood him to explain that "sometimes Windows 7 has a problem", as the drive is formatted for Windows 10, and the drive format is different for Windows 7. He suggested to hook it up to a Windows 10 machine, which my laptop is, and low and behold, it took off working on the Windows 10 machine. Then I took the drive back to my Windows 7 machine, and it started working. WEIRD !So, all in all, it works, but not without wasting about 2 hours trying to make it work. They could do better.
title: Don't try this on a Windows 7 Computer

author: Matthew Duerr
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2020
review_content: As the title says, the enclosure for my drive died a month in. It was working fine yesterday when I left work and refused to turn on when I got back in the morning. The light on the case was blinking, but the drive did not so much as make a sound or indicate that it was getting power. It was plugged in to a surge protector so I'm highly doubtful of an electrical failure on the building's part.This caused much stress and panic, since I thought I had lost my data completely. After much troubleshooting, I popped out the drive from the enclosure and into my PC where it proceeded to work again.Minus several stars for shaving years off my life. Original review follows:Product description claims speeds up to 160 MB/s, my original tests resulted in 30-40 MB/s during benchmark testing and ~25 MB/s during actual use.HOWEVER I tried again with a different USB cable than the one provided and the write speeds improved dramatically. Why on Earth they'd ship this with such an inferior cable is beyond me, but I feel much better knowing the product does what it says.
title: UPDATE: Enclosure failed after a month

author: Robert Bresten
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2020
review_content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video.           I bought this back in August and I have experienced technical issues since then. The device appears to be fine, I was able to upload up 12Tb of total data to this drive. The problem is a mechanical problem, the drive makes grinding and rumbling noises which you can audibly hear in the videos attached. All of them have had issues out of the box.I've contacted Seagate technologies 5 times since my initial issues began. I've received four replacements 3 with the same issues referenced above and the other being an issue with the cable input where I could not insert the USB cable to plugin the device to the computer. Seagate was very nice but the results are unsatisfactory to say the least. The worst part is that I'm now well past the return date so I'll have a fight in front of me to get my $350 back.
title: This product is terrible

author: Ken R
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2020
review_content: Connected this with the provided USB cable to the USB 3.x port on a new Alienware laptop.Transferring a bunch of files and the data speeds range from ~45MB/s all the way down to ~700KB/s (!!!). Average is below 10MB/s. Not remotely close to the advertised specs.Outrageous.Tech supports: only thing to recommend is defrag and format the drive.Again, Outrageous.There's NO reason to defrag then format a drive. Or visa-versa. None the less I had Windows take a look at it: 0% fragmented (of course).Should I have to reformat a brand new, pre-formatted drive? Only if the manufacturer really screwed up.So far it's taken the better part of two days to back up less than 1.5 Terabytes of data.Well, poop, guess it'l be going back.
title: It's Not Slow. It's Slooooooow.

author: Stephen Hall
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 28, 2020
