review_content: I thought I needed an 8TB drive, but this 10TB was the same price.  I can't say, after only a couple of months, if the hard drive is quality and will last a long time.  Seagate is hit-and-miss on drives, like most other brands.But then: this is just one of two backup hard drives. Because we all run backups every month, right!?  :-)  So if it fails, just get another one.  Okay, not a glowing review. But then, so long as you stick to 1st tier hard drive makers, I think we are getting as good as it gets:  Seagate, Western Digital, and Hitachi/IBM.For every external drive, not just this one:  Be SURE to set your Windows Device Manager, Disk Drive, "Policy" on this drive to disable Windows caching. Otherwise, you'll not get amazing speeds on any external device.  This means you'll have to go old-school with "ejecting" the device from the System Tray to assure everything is closed-off on the drive before disconnecting.  A minor extra step which is easily compensated by the faster copy times.
title: I'll never fill this up - famous last words

author: YouShouldThinkThis:
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2019
review_content: I bought a 1TB device for my PS4 love it so far... I'm a gamer so i had no installation fears but I have to say it was extremely easy, a child could to set it up, plug in, navigate to storage and its pretty much automatic clicking X to accept formating...i just don;t like that fact that it is advertised at 1TB but uses 80GB to format the hard drive for PS4 use? seems like an incredible amount of data space loss to me for that process.  Unless some of the devices 1TB of storage is used already in prepartion for use.... next time just make it 1.080GB... i dont mind paying an extra $1
title: NOT a whole TERABYTE, missing 80GB?

author: K. L.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2019
review_content: It's cheap, and I need long term storage I rarely access so I wasn't expecting much...USB 3.0 should be pretty fast, right? I normally get 80-100 megabytes per second transfer on this same USB 3.0 port. This drive is running at 2, sometimes 3.Three megabytes per second. Seriously guys, this is pathetic.Also, keep in mind while it says 4 trillion bytes available, your computer is going to list 3.63 TB not 4.0 TB. (I realize this is standard, just putting it here for anyone who is expecting more)I don't see how this has so many 5 star reviews. I don't mind a cheap fairly slow storage device for what I need, but this is unacceptable.
title: Just as slow as everyone else says

author: John
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2020
review_content: Ordered one of these thinking that the price seemed about right for a 1TB these days and its sold by Amazon, so it will probably be fine. These are FAKE FAKE FAKE, even before getting it completely out of the packaging things seemed off. So (thanks to the cheap transparent plastic packaging) I compared the drive to my seagate 1TB and things were not right, the logo on the front was hollow and not raised with metal like the real one is and the light slit looked different. BUT WAIT, ok sure maybe this is just a newer model than mine and things have changed... So I check with Seagate about the serial number and it comes back fine BBBUUUUUUTTTTT! it doesn't match the model number. So now we have two strikes and the batter steps into the box.... pitcher winds up and flies one in to the catcher (he also notices the address of the headquarters in the bottom corner of the hard drive and starts to question life and how the Seagate Singapore International Headquarters is both in Singapore and also apparently in The Netherlands)... STRIKE THREE!!!!!!!!TL;DR: Item was a fake, do not waste your money and risk personal and important information .
title: DO NOT BUY, ITS A FAKE!!!

author: Kay R.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2019
review_content: Sounded great when I ordered it, but it would not work on my desktop computer that runs Windows 7. I don’t know why. The computer would not recognize this external hard drive. Maybe tech support would have given me some answers, but I chose to return this item. My rating simply reflects what I’ve written here. This device might be just what someone else needs, and work great for them. So don’t take my one star rating as the norm for this device. Could be it doesn’t work on an older computer like mine.
title: Didn’t Work For Me

author: Riboild
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2019
review_content: First off this drive is right in the sweet spot of having enough storage but not being too expensive.  I got it for a bit over 120 but considering the 10tb was over 60 more, I think I got a great deal.  I will say this though, throw the cable that comes with it away and get yourself a quality 24ga or better one.  The USB B to A cable that is roughly about 2 feet long IS JUNK!!!  I couldn't get it to get any higher than 50 MB/s and I was like uhm, my backup plus drive which completely utilizes the bus to power it was getting 120-150MB/s so this should be WAY Faster...  And I was right.  I disconnected the cable after cancelling a backup of Acronis, and ejected it, removed power cord then USB and replaced it with the one that came with my Seagate Backup Plus and it immediately jumped to 200MB/s and kept going, dropping only to about 190MB/s  So I can testify this drive is completely bottleknecked by the darn cable it comes with.  I saw others with similar problem, and I was certain it was what indeed it was, an inferiour costcutting measure that sucks for the customer especially when they don't know why it's so slow.  For me, who has several cables lying around, including some from monoprice, I dropped a 3 footer that is now making life a lot easier, as the BUP had only a 18" cable.  Drive is humming along, and I have a little fan near it for temp sake, as I am now backing up my server which has a raid 5 consisting of 3-4TB SAS Seagate constellations ES.3 drives.  It took a while since it was about half full lol, but at ~200MB/s it didn't take as long as the BUP did.  Really nice drive and very sparkly lol.  I will say I hate having to plug in a backup drive but for my server I had to since it's kinda difficult to find any 8-10TB external drives that only use USB 3.0 Power.  This will do fine though as it will see minimal use only around once a month or more...
title: Drive needs a better USB B - A cable otherwise you are capped at abysmal speeds...

author: nate nicholson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2020
review_content: I bought one of these a couple weeks ago for my thousand-dollar Android cell phone and upon plugging it in the device was corrupted. I figured it was just a fluke so I sent it back and got a new one, plugged it into my Android phone, and it corrupted again. I received a third replacement and this time tried it with my 2017 iPad Pro using the Apple supported dongle for plugging in USB external hard drives, and it absolutely would not read a write any information to my iPad, it said there was not enough storage capacity, which led me to believe it was all so corrupted, but the odd part is it worked fine with my desktop computer. Maybe they started using cheaper supplies during covid-19 but right now they will absolutely not work with my mobile devices. So I've been through three of these and none of them have worked for me, I'm going to try a Western digital hard drive now.
title: Definitely does not work with iPad or Android mobile devices

author: Christine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2020
review_content: This is how this Seagate Portable 5TB External Hard Drive HDD arrived. In a brown paper bag, no protection, inside the plain brown hassle free packaging (that I did not request), and Not in a Seagate manufacturers box. I don't trust it. Sorry, I sent it back. No thanks.
title: Ummm no

author: Doctor A.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2020
review_content: Wow, 1 terabyte of storage for just a few bucks. This would have been unbelievable just a decade ago. This handy little drive should store all the data any individual or small business probably needs.At the beginning of each year, I back-up all my personal data files, favorites, contacts, photos, etc. on this tiny little gadget. Even with tons of data files and a bazillion hi-res photos (I'm a serious photographer), I barely put a dent in the 1TB capacity. This miniature drive meets my personal needs perfectly. However, more frequent back-ups would probably be appropriate for a business.In addition, this drive works well for updating and transferring my latest desktop files to my travel laptop. It is super fast using USB 3 and always glitch-free. Also, I purchased a simple zip case for storage in my home safe. Nice! From several reviews and forum comments, it seems Seagate continues with its solid customer support should it ever be required. I could not be more pleased with my purchase of this handy little external drive. Highly recommended.
title: An Essential Tool In This Digital Age

author: R. Caymo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2020
review_content: This is probably the biggest but not the best size external HD I have ever owned. After 2 days of transferring 2tb worth of data from my old Toshiba external to this harddrive it seems to be doing ok.Although now for some reason, if I ever try to dump a large amount of data to it (like 500gb), it seems to dip to 0kb then disconnect... and it happens pretty often.  I did all the power saving tricks you can do to these things and still does the same thing.I tried a Seagate external a very long time ago and I thought it was a POS.  Boy they haven't changed at all! I will probably buy another brand worthwhile and make this one a primary for my PS4,  it seems to be good for that at least.UPDATE: I have now reduced this to 1 Star because now, I have files that are now stuck on this drive! The dam thing keeps crashing when I try to move files off it! GARBAGE! Just give me my files back so I can return you! 🤯
title: Lots of space at a good price, but its functionality is questionable

author: MIKE
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2019
review_content: I'm using this specifically for my PS4 and it's as simple as plug into console, format, and copy/move games over. It's really that easy. Took about an hour and fifteen minutes to move Modern Warfare, Apex Legends, and Borderlands 3 over from console to HDD. I have the original Destiny edition PS4 and it only comes with 500GB so this was much needed. I have had to delete so many games over the years to maintain storage but now I won't have to worry about that issue. I regret that I waited so long to get this. A USB hub will not be able to sufficiently power this, it must be plugged directly into the console USB port. I feel like navigating the PS4 dashboard is much more fluid and smoother and the game load times have improved a little bit.
title: Works with PS4

author: The_Phantom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2020
review_content: UPDATED REVIEW, 17 JUN 2020:Okay, so originally I rated this drive 2/5 stars because the transfer speed was so slow.  However, I bought two of these drives and made a second back up on the second drive.  Lo and behold, the second time the backup was much, much faster and only took about 4 1/2 hours to complete the transfer of 766GB of data (Music - 100K+ songs).  I'm not really sure why it went nearly 6 times faster the second time as compared to the first time.  I would swear that I plugged the drive into a USB 3.0 port (Blue) the first time, too.  However, for whatever reason, the first time I backed up the music collection, it took nearly 24 hours to complete, but the second time it took about 4.5 hours.  So perhaps my computer is to blame? At this point, I really don't know.  I can only say that the second time around was a LOT faster and I was EXTREMELY pleased with the rate of transfer, as it was in line with what I was expecting for a drive that is supposed to support USB 3.0, which has a theoretical max speed of 120Mbps.  So averaging 60Mbps is more than reasonable and I saw it get up to 90Mbps for transfer speeds at times, too.So, after the second try, I will rescind my previous rating of 2/5 stars and raise it to 4.5/5 stars.  The only reason I'm not giving it the full 5/5 stars is that there is still doubt in my mind as to what happened with the other drive. Hopefully, you will have the same luck as I had with the second drive.  For $50, its a great deal no matter what, provided you're only using it for making backups and not a "working" drive that will be constantly accessed throughout the day.I bought this drive expressly to make a copy of my 766GB music collection.  I liked the price a lot and that the drive was capable of USB 3.0, which I also have on my Desktop computer.  Upon receipt of the drive, I checked the cable to make sure it was also USB 3.0 (it's blue inside, that's how you can tell).  Then I plugged it into my Desktop computer on a corresponding USB 3.0 port (Blue).  The desktop computer recognized the drive without issue and I then began the process of copying over my 766GB music collection from the Music folder on my computer to a Music folder on the new drive.  What I did not anticipate was that it would take nearly 20 hours to complete the transfer and at an average transfer speed of about 10MB/s.  As a result, this drive is only good for making backups and nothing more.  So if you have the time and are short on $$$, this drive does still have value.  But if you are in any kind of hurry, this drive is not the drive you want - not even close.  You can see the screen shots I took from beginning to end of the file transfer process to get a better idea of what I'm talking about.The Good- This drive costs just under $50- This drive is very portable and doesn't require a secondary power sourceThe Bad- This drive is extremely slow, despite using USB 3.0, which has a theoretical transfer speed of 120 MB/s. *  *NOTE: Theoretical is the keyword here.  It would be reasonable to expect a transfer speed of 60 MB/s over a  USB 3.0 connection.- This drive should only be used for backups and not a "working drive" I.E. one that you are constantly having to  access throughout your work day.Rating: 2/5 stars.  I'm giving it 2 stars for portability and price.  I'm subtracting 3 stars for how ridiculously slow the write speed is for a drive that is supposed to be USB 3.0 compliant, but transferred my music collection at what appeared to be USB 2.0 speeds.
title: Fantastic Price, Better performance than previously thought

author: Mark A. Handy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2019
review_content: Wanted to save some money instead of investing in a NAS or having a portable harddrive  Purchased this harddrive to hook up to my Netgear router via USB and use ReadyShare app, by Netgear, to access files remotely or on home network.  Needed a harddrive with no built in NAS ability or software. Harddrive is quiet where I have it.  Works great for storing files.  It is only one harddrive so there is no RAID setup, but I am good with that.
title: Using as NAS with ReadyShare Netgear Router

author: Lewis A Edge Jr
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2020
review_content: Working as a consult in the pharmaceutical and medical device industry, my wife must main a large collection of valuable files that would be painful and possibly costly to use.Using Acronis backup software my wife can run multiple full back-ups of her laptop hard drives with this USB external drive.  Then she can disconnect the drive to protect it from any potential virus infestations.Having full backups allows her to completely restore all of her files, software and operating system in the unlikely event that her SSD drive were to fail or become infected.This hard drive operates at a decent speed but is not as fast as an SSD, but that kind of speed is not needed when she can run her full backups at night within a couple of hours and then have Acronis automatically shut down her laptop and this hard drive.Interestingly, this external hard drive has no power switch.  It automatically turns itself on and off in response to requests from its USB port.  So far this hard drive has performed well and my wife's data has been secure.
title: Enough Capacity For Multiple Back-Ups

author: Peter Gabriel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2019
review_content: I've seen a lot of reviews mentioning slow write speeds.  Currently I am transferring 43G of music.  Windows is reporting a speed of 25 MB/s (average, 23-27 up and and down).  I placed my ear right on it and I can't hear a thing.  Configuration above all else when reporting write speeds.  Here is mine:WIndows 10 ProIntel NUC 8i7HVKVA (admittedly, this thing is a monster) 16G RAM 1TB SSDSource drive: Port: Front USB 3.0 (blue),  Seagate Expansion, Model: SRD00F2, Format: NTFS, Capacity: 4TBDest drive: Port: Back Top Right (while looking at it) USB 3.0 (blue), Model :The one in this review (it's transferring now and I dare not touch it to turn over and see the actual model number), Format: NTFS, Capacity: 8TBWhy four stars ....  I get the capacity thing, truly I do.But nothing hurts more than buying an 8TB drive and seeing windows only report 7.25TB.  That's close to 12.5%.  Over 10% right off the top (grrrrrrrrrrr).  And the bigger the drive, the percent stays the same-ish.Double the size of the drive to 16TB, you'd loose 2 whole TB.  Before the flames start ....I know it's not "lost" it a difference in calculation equations between Microsoft and ALL hard drive manufactures.  But 2 whole TB is a lot of difference between the two calculations.  Enough so, I felt compelled to mention in.I will update this review occasionally.  Right now it's performing very well doing write only.
title: Looks pretty good to start with

author: Christine D. Hunter
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2019
review_content: I liked this hard drive because it has a lot of storage, 8TB.  I don't like this hard drive because I bought it November 1, 2018 and here it is November 11, 2019 and it's gone bad.  If I would have thought to investigate in October, when I first noticed an issue, maybe it could have been replace because I believe it has a 1 year warranty.  I was working on a set of files and they just disappeared.  I thought maybe it was something I did, but no, it happened again.  The disk has been checked and now it's starting to fail.  It has Uncorrectable Sector Count so I guess when I reached a certain amount of data (near 5TB) it didn't like it writing to that area on the disk and files just disappeared.  I do have a backup service, but because some files disappeared quickly and I did not catch it until a couple weeks later, I lost those.  I have 5TB of data I need to put somewhere.  Just a note, this hard drive has sat in the same spot on my desk the entire time.  The only time it's moved is to dust.  This is the 1st hard drive I've had that has given me trouble within a year.  Going to 4 TB or less.
title: Only A Year Old And Is Failing :(

author: James Christopher Sagebiel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2020
review_content: I have several of these. They work great with my PC. For Macs, they have to be formatted, and I have had some that simply will not, for some reason, stay formatted for Mac. Tech support was not helpful, just instruct you to change the format. You read that correctly, I have formatted to Mac and the drive degrade where it is no longer readable by my Mac. Bye bye data on those drives, but I have then used the same drive with no issues for my Windows computers. I have had drives that simply refuse to format to a Mac-readable format. I would love to see one of these that is hot-swappable from Mac to Windows, but at least having them reliably useful for Macs would be great. My advice is (1) don't rely on these for an archive of your Mac data - have redundancy, (2) be prepared to return it if you are using it for a Mac, because it may not work.
title: Only sometimes works with Mac

author: R. Duncan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2020
review_content: I have bought three of these drives now. Two of them failed in the same way within 2 weeks of turning them on. In both cases, the drive will no longer mount, the white light on the top stays on continually, the disk repair utility hangs when it tries to access the drive. This is terrible quality control. I am not buying any more Seagate drives. I am going to return the third one as it has not even been turned on yet. Thank goodness for Amazon's wonderful hassle-free return policies. Amazon gets 5 stars, Seagate gets 1 star (if i could give zero stars, I would).Update - I decided to keep the third one after all and hope for the best. Sure enough, after 6 months, it failed completely just like the first two. No more Seagate drives for me!
title: Not reliable - 3 of these have failed in succession

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: We normally never leave bad reviews but this one is worth mentioning. Had to get two before finally having to return them. The first one came and as I am doing my business, it froze and then crashed. It did that an additional two more times. So replaced that one and the next one was just as bad. Reformatted it and it was working fine until it didn’t. It literally disappeared and I couldn’t find it whatsoever which means it was broken. I looked for it on two computers, as wel as in recovery modes and no luck. I would not recommend this product. The speeds were also awful in response time. Very confused as to how this had so many positive reviews. It does appear that in recent months the reviews are more negative than positive.
title: I would not recommend

author: tartakd
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2019
review_content: It takes about 10 days (!!!) to fill the 8TB hard drive with data, half of which is large files on USB-3.  That's why this company never writes the average (!!!) speed of file transfer on the packages and on the web site.  The drive capacity on NTFX (Windows 10) is 7.37TB.Update 1 hour later.  I rebooted the computer and now the speed of file transfer went up from 10-20MB/s to 120-140MB/s.  I did not touch the connections of the drive.  Now the file transfer is as fast as can be expected.  I do not know if the problem was Seagate's or Microsoft's, I do not know if it will reoccur or not.  For now I'm updating the rating from 1 star to 4.Update Next Day:  The speed of the drive is still good, but it caused the speakers on the computer to stop working.  Took me an hour of tinkering to bring them back.  Downgraded this drive to 3 stars.
title: Slow Speed, Low Capacity.  Speed Suddenly Changed to Normal.

author: The AngelArs Foundation
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2020
review_content: With this hard drive there are good points and there are bad points. First the good. The hard drive (inside the enclosure) is of good quality and works very well. The bad news is that the enclosure Seagate made for this drive is complete garbage. It is made from cheap (and very, very thin) aluminum and is only slightly thicker than aluminum foil. Even worse and more to the point, it does not connect properly to the computer.In fact that's the whole reason why I had to remove the drive from the enclosure.  Once I installed the drive in a properly designed enclosure the hard drive connected flawlessly, and everything was fine. I tried other known good hard drives with the Seagate enclosure, and they too would not connect. Of course removing the drive from the enclosure will void your warranty, so I don't recommend you do this unless you're an experienced tech. It's a shame that Seagate decided to enclose their well built hard drive inside such a mickey mouse style enclosure. The hard drive (inside the other enclosure) works flawlessly. Just know that if you buy this drive and it has issues connecting, it's probably not the hard drive itself, but the flimsily made enclosure.
title: The good and the bad...

author: Isabel E
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 18, 2020
review_content: I needed to transfer over 500 videos not to mention tons of pictures off my computer, so I purchased this 2TB external hard drive.  However my mac couldn't see it... it was not appearing as another device at all.  I called the customer service number and a very professional, knowledgeable and polite customer service rep. knew exactly what to do and helped me through several steps to get it to work!  This copied everything over so quickly.  I'm impressed with this Seagate product and with their customer service!  I will be purchasing Seagate products in the future.
title: Great Product

author: Mark Huth
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2019
review_content: I wanted to use this for periodic backups of my linux desktop system.  Unfortunately, it will not maintain reasonable write speeds after about 16 GB have been transferred.  From 50 to 100 MB per second, the write rate falls to under 1 MB per second after about 16 GB were transferred.It took almost an hour to unmount after I halted the backup.  Major garbage, not suited to the purpose unless you only transfer small amounts of data at a time.
title: Not much of a backup drave, since it craps out at arount 16GB

author: Lare
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2020
review_content: I'm not impressed with this drives write speed. I have about 5 TB's of data to copy to the drive and it's very slow. It indicates it will take more than a day to finish. My other external USB 3.0 external drives have at least 4x the write speed of this drive. It's only getting about 20 MB/s in transfer speed and the other external drives get close to 100 MB/s.UPDATE: I was about ready to send the drive back because of the slow write speed, but first decided to try a different USB 3.0 cable from one of my WD external drives. The write speed went from 20 MB/s to 160-180 MB/s after replacing the cable. Evidently the cable that came with the Seagate drive must be a USB 2.0 cable, even though it has the blue connector tip indicating it to be USB 3.0. Happy with the drive now, but not happy with the cable that was included. New USB 3.0 cable on order.
title: Very slow

author: Alderaan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2020
review_content: I bought a 5TB harddrive, because I kept running out of storage on my rig (1 TB). I didn't want to bother with a SSD (Internal Solid State Drive), because I'm not good with opening up electronics. I wanted to play it safe and just plug something into the USB port.It's very easy to set up. Just open the packaging, plug the HHD into your PC, and go through a quick set-up screen. Register your HHD for extra security.I have no issues with it thus far. I've transferred entire games through Steam (50+ GB games) in a matter of minutes. Downloads games at the same speed as downloading directly to my PC. Loading times seem to be the same as well. Note, that I primarily play singleplayer games. Multiplayer games *may* or may not run a little slower. For gamers that are worried about that: put your MP games on your PC, and use the HHD for mostly SP games.
title: Great for gaming!

author: Kyle Cook
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2020
review_content: The 5tb version is a model ST5000LM000, 2.5" 15mm drive. I shucked it to install into my Ubiquiti UniFi Cloud Key Gen2 Plus (UCK-G2-PLUS) and it works great. The case on this drive has very tight tolerances so use a guitar pick or very flat plastic blade to pop the case off. I removed the 1TB drive from my Ubiquiti Cloud Key and installed the 5TB from this case. The 1TB went back in this case for backups. Takes about 15 minutes to do the swap.
title: 5TB FITS UBIQUITI CLOUD KEY

author: Lars Spears
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2019
review_content: I mostly play story driven single player games and mainly come online for either DLC  and updates for the PS4 console system and game apps.  My gripe with the PS4 pro is the stock memory capacity.  I recently ran out of space on my 1 TB stock internal. I discovered the cause of this were mainly DLC and updates.  I research in to some solutions on this issue on reddit.  I was decisive on purchasing Seagate FireCuda 2TB Solid State Hybrid Drive; I been recommended to change the internal. Suddenly from a reddit post.  I received a different view point on using an External HDD instead. I was recommended the one I'm reviewing.My Problem: I want to be able to keep all my game apps, updates, and overall data.  I don't like the idea to delete and re-download everything when I need to make space in my 1 TB stock memory.  Due to my local area having crappy ISP and internet speed 30-55mbps I have to leave my PS4 on few days when it comes to files been over 100GB.Overall: If you have a similar problem like me.  Get this HDD.  It's a remedy and you have plenty of space to keep all your game apps files.  You just never know when the internet might be unavailable. in you won't have access to get all DLC and updates you just deleted alone with the game app.
title: Best PS4 External Storage upgrade to invest.  Especially if you're offline frequently.

author: Greg
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2019
review_content: This is a great external hard drive and the cost is very reasonable, especially if you compare it with the ANNUAL fee charged by Microsoft to store your files for ONE computer.  You can use it on any computer. About the time to download issue that so many post about. The download time depends on the computer you are using. If you have a cheap or older computer it will take longer. I have a classic car club on Facebook and have over FOUR YEARS of pictures and videos I downloaded to my computer amoung other things. It took about 3 hours on my 5 year old computer.  I think that is very reasonable for my out of date computer. I also what to thank Amazon to get it to me in FOUR HOURS.  That's right, FOUR HOURS.  I was amazed. I LOVE Amazon!!!
title: This is a GREAT external hard drive. I'm shocked by some of the reviews.

author: S. Kes
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2020
review_content: I bought this drive again to expand my storage since the first was so good. This newer one I received was less than one third of the transfer speed of the first one. Advertised at 160 mbps, I was averaging 24mbps. Hooked up the original drive I received on the same USB cable connected to the exact same port tried to move the same files and was clocking between 80 to 175 mbps transfer speed. This drive crawls, at least the one I received did  and I had to send it back. The two dives look identical, but my first drive had a blue bottom, and this one has a black bottom. Not sure if they changed the design and internals, but when I reordered the "same drive" from my order history, the second one was defiantly not the same speed as the first; it averaged 4 times slower. This may not matter with small data backups, but moving over 8TB will take days, not hours!
title: Not the same drive I bought 6 months ago SLOW

author: Catherine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2020
review_content: I bought this in November 2019, by March 2020 it had connectivity issues. I replaced the USB cables and tried different ports, but connectivity remains intermittent. There is no indication of imminent device failure it just suddenly disconnects from my Windows 10 OS. I receive an I/O error message. All problems disappear upon reboot, but it is very annoying.I use this device to store video files. I'm glad I'm not using it as a 'working' drive as I think access would be a nightmare.I generally like the Seagate brand, but I'm underwhelmed by this device's performance and glitchy connectivity. I don't recommend it.
title: Started Out OK, but Connectivity Issues Ensued - BEWARE!

author: Debbie Lee Wesselmann
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2020
review_content: I bought this portable hard drive to use as back-up drive that I can store off-site, and the small size makes it especially useful for that.  I chose this Seagate portable drive over the WD I also bought to use on my husband's PC becasue it explicitly said that it was Mac-compatible, while the WD said I'd have to reformat.  While that's more or less true, this Seagate did not work with my Mac right out of the box. It comes in read-only format.  I had to download an updated NTFS for Macs program so that I could write on it.  While that solution works well, I had to research the problem on the internet since Seagate does not provide instructions on what to do.But the drive itself works flawlessly now that I have NTFS on my Mac.  The write speed is fast.  Because I'm not running any programs off of it and instead am using it to back-up files only, the speed is good enough for me -- it's faster than the older external drives I use for home back-ups.  It comes with a USB 3.0 cable that is backward compatible with USB 2.0, so your speeds will be dependent on whether you have a 2.0 or 3.0 port and limited by the technology of both.  If you need a faster connection, get a drive with a USB C or Thunderbolt connection that can connect to the appropriate port on your computer.  And if you need speed, consider an  SSD drive.The drive is slightly smaller than my hand -- and I don't have large hands.  It is a non-powered drive -- that is, it is powered through the USB drive rather than through a wall outlet.Other than my initial frustration figuring out how to make the drive compatible with my Mac, this drive has turned out to be exactly what I wanted.-- Debbie Lee Wesselmann
title: Not Exactly Compatible With Macs Out of the Box, But With Good Back-Up Speed

author: Lunix
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2019
review_content: Update 2020-05-20:  I got burned by Seagate again.  I'm done with them.  I just hope I can recover some files.  I use this mostly for disk image backup (typically 32GB or 64GB each) for embedded systems.  I've had this for about 10 months.  It gets used very very seldom.  But I keep having to scan this NTFS-formatted drive and repair it.  Today, Windows (latest patches of version 10) said it would take 1:15 (HH:MM), then it puked at about 4:45 remaining (yes, it went up several times during the repair).  And this thing is incredibly slow, despite my previous update.  It seemed to slow down as it got more full, and the longer it was connected to a computer.  I copied many files to it in Linux, and by the time I gave up and decided to check it under Windows, it was writing at about 200kB every five seconds (about 40kB/sec) on that Linux machine- which has two 4TB drives from WD that are working constantly for at least a year.Update:  It's been a few days since I wrote the initial review below (on 2019-07-20).  My PC has been powered off (thanks to a neighborhood power failure) since then.  I am writing some 100+ GB files and am getting speeds between 94 and 126 MB/sec now (varies between those over time).  I will check the read speed later.  I couldn't let my previous review stand.Original review:  This thing is incredibly slow. Sequential writes happen at about 26MB/s, reads at a bit more than 100 (using a USB 3.0 connection that gets me about 4x the write speeds with other drives).  I've been burned by Seagate drives a few times, and pretty much stick to WD, and Samsung.  I do have a few 6+ year-old Seagates that get occasional use as backup drives.  I don't know if I can live with the slow speeds of this drive.  And if I do, I am not sure it will last very long.  I will report back after a year or so, if I keep it for another week.
title: Slooooow and error-prone

author: Harrison Gordon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2019
review_content: I have had this for about a week. It is to replace my WD passport 2tb backup drive and to save space on a bunch of other drives. I first put all of my files on, then tried moving my Time Machine backups. Because of the terrible way that Mac moved the database, I've had a bit of a rough road getting that over to the drive but let's just say that I have learned that while Black magic Disk speed test claims it's got 130MB/s up down, in reality, transferring a terabyte takes more than eight hours. And moving 20 gb takes....about 40 minutes. It's just super slow and I can't imagine how it could be my unit so it seems like it's just built this way.Besides that please be aware that the quality of the casing is poor, so just be careful with it as it's easy to break the cable connections to the unit.
title: 8tb SOOOOO SLOOOOOW

author: EE Engineer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2020
review_content: I am an engineer and scientist so I know a thing or two about hard drives. Although they claim "Maximum Speed" of 160 MB/sec, that is hogwash. The highest transfer speed I can get is around 20-25 MB/sec. I also have a 2 TB drive I am writing to that easily achieves 120 MB/sec, so the computer can transfer files at that speed. It just seems that Seagate decided to scrimp on either the hardware or the platter speed (the platter is a magnetically-coated steel plate on which the one-and-zeros are stored), probably to make a price point. Where they got ""160 MB/sec" is a mystery (or a lie).You want 8 TB and don't care about transfer speed, then I guess this is your drive. You want to take 12 hours moving 2 TB onto a drive (which was last night's experience for me), then this is your drive. You want things faster? Then try another manufacturer. Perhaps Seagate will get the message and make a useful drive instead of this mess.
title: I agree - Painfully Slow Write Speed

author: MJ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: I purchased the 2tb version. Admittedly, I just got it, but so far it's working perfectly.I was alarmed at first, because it was randomly disconnecting and reconnecting. I wasn't even thinking about trying to do a backup or even not returning it at that point, but after using the "safely eject" method in windows and moving the usb connection to a port on the back of my tower and waiting about a half hour to see if it would maintain the connection, I was satisfied that it was just the port on the top of my computer.To be fair, half of all the usb ports on all of my electronics do that eventually, especially if you connect and disconnect routinely.Anyway, I then downloaded the seagate disc wizard from their website, which seems to be a free "light" version of Acronis. I wasn't thrilled with their "toolkit" option that you get initially when you register. I suppose that's just a personal preference, but it seemed similar to mobile apps that you run across these days where everything is over simplified.I used the disc wizard program to do a full backup of my system drive and it took 10 minutes. My system drive is an m.2 256gb ssd. before I go to bed tonight I'll start a full backup including the D drive which is a 1tb hdd. If I find that takes hours and hours I'll just forego the d drive backups. The d drive just contains some games that I can re-download from steam anytime anyway and some documents that get backed up on a flash drive every 10 minutes by windows file history. I've got plenty of room to move those to the c drive if I want a second backup on the seagate drive without regular backups of the d drive.I don't see how the other reviewers are having all these problems with the speed. Maybe it will become clearer when I try to do a larger backup.I'm using a relatively new (1 year old) I7 premium specs system, and I imagine there are many bottlenecks that one could encounter if using an older or just plain lower spec system. Maybe that could contribute to some of the negative reviews? Not that that would be the reviewers fault, but it wouldn't be Seagate's fault either. I'm just sayin'.I plan to update this review in a few days
title: I don't know what's with all the bad reviews.

author: J. Mason
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2020
review_content: I own two other Seagate USB drives (one is 2 Tb and the other is 3 Tb).  They have both been good external drives; so I just bought this Seagate 5 Tb drive.My first impression of this disc drive was, "Man, this thing is SLOW".  It took 7.5 hours to backup 3.4 Tb worth of data.  This same backup only took about 2-3 hours when I backed up the date to my older USB external discs.  (YES, I checked my USB cable ... and YES, it was fully seated on both ends.)Next, I ran some random checks on the data I had backed up.  Using a file comparison program, I discovered that 350 of my photo files did not copy onto this new disc drive.  Why?  Your guess is as good as mine.  There was nothing unusual (i.e.  filename, size, read/write attributes,  etc.) about the files that didn't copy.  Also, I didn't get any error or warning messages about the files that weren't copied.Another test I tried involved trying to deleting a nested folder that contained 50,000 photos, Window went through the motion of detecting the files; but then it didn't actually delete them.  This happened repeatedly.  The only way I could delete the files was to go down into the actual subfolder that contained them.Next, I tried connecting this disc drive to my husband's Dell XPS computer, which is still running Windows 7.  His computer said the disc drive had to be formatted before it could be used.I can't trust a disc drive that is this unreliable; so I initiated action to return it.  In the meanwhile, I started looking at other brand ... WD, Toshiba, etc.  Unfortunately, their ratings on them were pretty much on par with this Seagate drive; with many of the same problems.As I was clearing my data off of this 5 Tb disc drive, a light bulb came on in my brain.  I remembered  there was a time when Windows couldn’t access a disc drive that was larger than 2 Tb.  That made me wonder if the problems, copying and deleting files, were due to this disc drive’s large data capacity.  Perhaps, Windows 10 was "choking" on the size of this disc's file allocation table.I decided to partition this disc into 2 logical disc drives. Since I already have a separate 3 Tb USB disc drive, which works fine with Windows 10, I made one partition 3 Tb.  Then, I used the remaining free spaces for a second disc partition.  Next, I formatted both of these new partitions as NTFS.  This two partition configuration now seems to be work properly with Windows 10.This drive is still very SLOW; but at least partitioning it seems to have resolved the data accuracy problems.  Also, my husband’s computer can now recognize the separate disc partitions.
title: Almost returned it

author: big_art
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2020
review_content: I must have incredibly bad luck, or these drives are just not built to last for Time Machine backups.  I have three verified purchases on Amazon, including one exchange due to a drive going bad on me in 2 weeks.  So I've gone through four units total.As I write this, the last of the three went dead.  Just days ago I could hear it struggling to write, making ticking and clicking noises, while the motor made repeated attempts to spool up as evidenced by a "whine" sound.  Today is no longer shows up on my desktop and I can no longer backup to it.The other three went bad in differing ways.  One started getting disk errors before it would no longer record time machine backups.  I have used these on two different iMac's, exclusively as Time Machine backups.  Something in my setup does not agree with these.Very disappointing.
title: Purchased 3 units.  All failed within 1 year.

author: SP Camera DP
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2020
review_content: July 30, 2020Just received and started using this seagate hard drive. This specific drive has an all plastic housing. It is not the one with the metal top (that is available in different colors). I have a number of Seagate Backup Plus drives (with the colored metal tops), and they have performed quite well in time. I expect this one to also perform well, as the plastic top, in theory, should have no effect on performance. The drive is noticeably lighter in weight than the ones with a metal top. This hard drive is made in Thailand. The packaging was a generic cardboard box, easy to open. It included the USB-3 cable. The plastic top has a matted, slightly rough textured surface. It seems to be slightly wider and slightly longer than the metal top versions. Maybe 2mm or so.
title: Works

author: klee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2019
review_content: I have been buying only Seagate drives since 2003. I have bought both internal and external drives, both online and at local stores. I have never seen a Seagate drive packaged like this. This is very suspicious, unless Amazon had taken out the drives and repackaged it, which makes no sense to me. Why would they do that? I opened one of the package and the actual drive looks very suspicious as well, unless Seagate had redesigned it. I bought two 5TB portable drives like these from Costco last year. When comparing the two, they are completely different. Even the physical size is different. This one is slightly bigger. The USB port is not in the same spot. My Costco Seagate has the Seagate logo in front of the word "SEAGATE". This one doesn't. If you look closely, the font doesn't seem to be the same either. The P/N, serial number, and barcodes look faded. The P/N number on the drive doesn't match the P/N number on the box. Mine says, "Assembled in Thailand" and "Product of Thailand." This one says, "Assembled in China." Everything about this is very suspicious. I don't know if this is a Seagate product or not.Buy and use at your own risk.
title: Buy and Use at your own risk: Looks like a fake.

author: Mary I. Oliver
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2020
review_content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video.           No power cord; This Seagate does it all with just the USB cableA bit slower when copying 30GB of folders all at one time. My old large Seagate with the power cord was faster.But this new one is good, is fast.It is small, portable. Can store a lot; 4TB! Entire computer files fit. This is my extra backup.Old large 1TB Seagate lasted for years. Still works. Just getting full. Good products.CON; The connector to the Seagate falls out, becomes loose. Often results in losing full or partial data transfer; have to start all over. The larger, older/new Seagate; SAME faulty connector.  I will be searching for new brand if they do not fix this problem.My old Seagate was good; a strong connector, stayed fully plugged in.
title: Good! All files backed up! BUT

author: Bobby  W.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2020
review_content: I own a first gen PS4, and when I got it, I almost immediately wanted to upgrade the puny 500Gb onboard storage drive, but at that time, the only way to do so was to buy and mount a new internal drive.Since they were expensive at the time, and since I'm lazy, I just kept flushing lesser used games off the system to make room for new ones. But who doesn't like variety? I missed good old "Zombie Army Trilogy"!Flash forward to 2020, and with the latest version of the PS4 system software installed, you can easily add an external storage drive to your PS4 console - just make sure you read all of the information on Playstation's website before you do so (there's also useful 3rd party videos on YouTube, but I got the latest & straightest poop from Sony's website).A few obeservations:Again, contrary to what some other people have posted here, if you are considering this Seagate drive (and you have the current PS4 System Software installed) this drive will work! It's almost 'plug and play' - you do have to format the drive (this goes really quick), and you do have to specify that you want to use this drive for game storage when you first hook it up (actually, all of this is clearly explained onscreen once you plug in the drive and turn on your PS4).The drive comes with a shortish USB cable, which was sufficient length to plop the drive on top of your console.One side of the cable is the typical "Type A" connector, the other end is the micro super speed connector that  connects to the Seagate storage drive.  I don't know if I just wasn't looking close enough or if it's a thing with first gen PS4 systems, but I didn't see a "Type A" USB connector on the back of my console (just a USB "Type B" or printer type connector), so I ended up hooking this drive to one of the PS4's front panel USB ports. Works.This drive is pre-formatted for use with PC/Macs, so I was fearing a long reformat time on the PS4.  It actually only took about a minute.I bought the 4Tb drive - once formatted, the actual usable storage space on my PS4 is 3.68Tb (92%). I am not complaining.Final thought - if you are considering buying the 2Tb drive, I would suggest spending the extra money and getting the 4Tb drive.  Currently, there are always some really good deals on great title downloads from the Playstation store, and with the PS5 on the horizon, these deals will most likely continue - I'm glad I sprang for the extra room. If I stop using my PS4, I can always use an extra drive on my PC.  :)
title: YES, this works on PS4 - Consider the 4Tb

author: mike
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2020
review_content: good price for storage, reasonable transfer speed on usb 3.0 (74.4MB/s) go for the internal on usb 2.0 (20MB/s).You can see peak speeds up to 230MB/s on this drive but it has trouble with small files and average transfer rate ends up being 74.4MB/s on mixed files. For ref, one drive to NVME SSD is about 192mb/s on 200mb internet connection. I was impressed this was cheaper than the internal drive, but I suspect the internal would be a bit faster. No significant difference was observed by setting win10 policy to optimize transfer vs safe removal.Rank: NVME SSD>SSD>IntHDD >MSonedrive@200MB>this drive@USB3.0>>>>>this drive@USB2.0>USB drive on 2.0>>>UniVPNnetworkdrive = MSonedrive on wireless
title: good price for storage, reasonable transfer speed on usb 3.0 (74.4MB/s)

author: Adam Cole
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2020
review_content: Know that you're getting an SMR (shingled) drive, and know what that means.(*) Basically, they're good for archiving media & any WORM (write once, read many) scenario.If you try to use this for RAID, NAS, or as a typical all-purpose desktop hd, where the user or the OS randomly writes/erases/moves/defrags files, access will slow to a crawl & you'll get hangs or freezes once you've filled the drive with enough data to start shingling.This behavior REALLY sucks if you aren't expecting it. I learned this the hard way. Get a conventional hdd (or ssd) instead for these common applications.(*)Explanation: SMR drives cram more data onto a platter by physically overlapping one file with another, just like roofing shingles or a tandem garage. The drive can read the entire file back from just the exposed part of the "shingle" alone...no slowdown involved, as long as you're just reading what's there.But if you want to write to (move, modify, delete) a file in an already-shingled area, you first have to tear up & move ALL the overlapping shingles, replace the target(s), then retrieve & reinstall the others. You can easily imagine how much extra time that takes. Now imagine modifying or moving hundreds of small files or pieces of files, or rebuilding a RAID mirror set, or defragmenting a drive that's over half full...massive, aggravating traffic jam.
title: Users & shuckers beware!

author: John Stewart
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2020
review_content: This drive makes the loud noises that get annoying quickly. I use this for an Xbox in a home theater and had another one I got for an office backup. They’re both loud enough I’m getting rid of them. They run the disk randomly so you hear the fans and cooling kick on. What’s weird is when it does it there’s a significant digital distortion signal coming from the drive that almost sounds like a boot cue soundbite. If it happened a few times while in use it wouldn’t be a big deal but it does it every 3-7 minutes non stop. It’s annoying enough that it’s now defeated the meticulous sound treatments I’ve done to both my home theater and digital production office
title: Noisy

author: li'l bamboo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2020
review_content: This says it is for windows and mac, it is formatted for windows and you need to format it for a mac yourself.Before I say this is not a good product I'll have to say my mac has some issues.  I haven't been able to upgrade the operating system for some time and it could be part of the issue I have in trying to format the disc.  It won't format the disc because apparently I don't have the correct OS.Getting this I realize I no longer need such a large external drive.  I've decided to change my method of backup and I'll be happy with it.I think mostly I was looking for a plug and use mac drive and this isn't it.  It could be if you are able to do the formatting and set it up.  I didn't want to go through the hassle of setting up the disc.I've used Seagate discs for nearly forty years and have always been satisfied with them, sadly not this time.
title: this is formatted in Windows

author: Charles
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2020
review_content: My first impression of this heating pad is pretty positive. What you see is what yo get. It is as "plush" as Sunbeam's so-called "plush" heating pad and it fits nicely to my back. I have a 33 - 34 in waist and the belt fits me fine and I believe it would fit a larger person easily. Not to take anything away from the heating pad,  but I have to say if your waist is under 33 - 34 in. it's going to fit very loosely.  I have it cinched as far as it will go and it's not necessarily tight, but a comfortable fit. It would probably be snugger if i had a shirt or a sweat shirt on, but I'm not complaining.  I agree that it heats up pretty quickly, although I wish it were a bit hotter. Still, it's at least as hot as any Sunbeam product, of whom I've become increasingly frustrated with over the years. Sunbeam is not near as good as it used to be that they seem to just die right out of the box. The longevity of this heating pad remains to be seen, but at this price, if it outlasts my last several Sunbeam products I'm money ahead, especially if the manufacture makes good on the warranty: 5 years with a 365 day free replacement & 90 days free return. That adds up to a whole lot of happy for me. You can't touch a Sunbeam product like this for under forty dollars.  Believe me--I looked everywhere. Also, it shopped very quickly. It's eligible for free shipping. I ordered in on Saturday and got it on Monday. Best buying experience I've had for a long time. Even if I only get a year out of it--I would buy it again. Let's hope I get at least a year out of it. I certainly don't trust a Sunbeam product to last that long.
title: As good as Sunbeam if not Better!

author: Jennyfrijole
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2020
review_content: WOW. Okay, so I've had a 1TB Seagate External Hard Drive for years now, maybe five or so? And after lots of data transfers and moving it from computer to tv to laptop constantly and dropping it a bunch of times, it finally started to glitch on me. Since it lasted a long time and worked so great, I went for another Seagate with a lot more space.I had it for two weeks, and it worked fine. It was plugged into a desktop in an upstairs office, and I needed it downstairs for my laptop. So I went and grabbed it, but when I hit the second to last step coming down, my foot slid out from under me, and I went down to the ground, HARD. I landed flat on my front, and I had thrown my hands out to catch myself, which meant I slammed that hard drive flat on the ground with all my weight behind it. It then shot out from under my palm and slid across the floor, hitting a wall.I thought that was it. When I picked it up, the casing had come apart on one side, the chord had disconnected - no way this thing would ever work again. Plugged it into my laptop, and sure enough, it wouldn't read it. Neither of my laptops would, and neither of the TVs would. I thought I'd just smashed $115.The next day, though, I decided to give it one last shot, so I CAREFULLY went back upstairs and plugged it into the desktop. THANK GOD it worked - I assumed the desktop just had better ports and I quickly transferred all the data off it, while also reordering the drive again (along with a heavy duty one because I'm clumsy, obviously). Once it was empty, I reformatted it, and since it was working so well on the desktop, I transferred one of my videos back on to it, then took it back down to test on a TV.IT WORKED! I've since put more stuff on it, and thus far it's working FINE! Across ALL devices! Like ... what kind of wizardry is this!? I couldn't have been rougher on it if I'd literally thrown it at the ground, I slammed it that hard - and after just letting it sit for a night and then reformatting it, the drive works fine! I mean, I wouldn't trust it enough to store something on it without backing it up first, but thus far, it's like nothing happened to it.Based on that alone, I one million percent recommend this drive!ETA: When I got this product originally two weeks ago, it shipped in a plain, slim, brown box, inside a snug clear plastic container, with one little leaflet for an instructional manual. I was like okie dokie, whatever, as long as it works. Then I thought it was strange that when I went to reorder it, the black one would no longer ship to my address (I'm in Mexico), considering I'd just gotten it two weeks ago, but whatever, I just got the silver, color doesn't matter.It just arrived, and this silver version came in a very official looking product box, with the Seagate logo on it, and lots of instructions and special offers inside, all perfectly sealed with tamper-evident tape. Even the casing on the actual drive seems dramatically different. So ... was the black one a refurbished item?
title: I SLAMMED IT AGAINST THE GROUND AND IT STILL WORKS

author: B-Zing
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2020
review_content: I was looking for a new drive that I could use as a “backup” for my iPad, iPhone, computer, etc.  I tried other tech like thumb drives, other Hard drives, they claimed to be plug and play but it seemed I always had some kind of issue once I plugged them in.  With this drive, it actually lived up to it’s name.  I did have to buy a USB-C cable to connect this drive to my iPad, but soon as I connected it could read the drive and transfers files with no issues or added instructions.  2Tb is definitely large enough for my files, pictures and music.  I can now keep my inner peace knowing that my info is backed up and kept safely in my firebox.  I know someone may say that I could keep my backup on the cloud.... but to be quite honest, I have seen to many movies to trust the cloud when the end of the world comes... I’d rather have all my data in my Levi jeans pocket while I’m hiding in a bunker waiting for the radiation to subside... ; )
title: Inner Peace Maintained!

author: WriterInFact
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2020
review_content: Can't speak about tech support since it hasn't been needed (I know, and it's even hardware, right?). This is so portable it's cross-platform portable, and I love it! I have moved my personal library (what isn't trapped in Kindle) to this 1TB external drive - almost double the 7000 items in Kindle. Even better, I recently bought a 2TB drive to collect all my videos in one place, too. Now I just need to find a place to put my other collections ... maybe another drive will come my way for Mother's Day! Nothing terrifies a software geek quite like hardware, but this has been completely painless. Thanks, Seagate.
title: Hip, Hip Hooray!

author: Greg Yoo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2020
review_content: Packaging was shady. Looks like it could be fake.I have another seagate external hard drive which i've been using well for the last four years.I have two laptops and this one works fine on both.The new one only worked on one laptop. and the mount was significantly slower.It takes almost 15 seconds to mount which is not acceptable.The new one does not connect to another laptop. tried a few times but just doesn't work.So yeah, horrible experience that I have to exchange for a different model in this crisis.Took about two weeks to get this delivered. Will have to wait 10 days for the different one to arrive.Do not recommend.
title: Had to exchange to something else.

author: Mason
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2019
review_content: I was using a USB Hub since all of the USB ports are taken.I have 99% of data stores on 3 separate HDs; a long almost nightmare story behind that.I'm moving most of the data off onto this 2TB. A 1TB only holds 930GB. Any additional data will take time to fill this one.Transferring large amounts of data through a USB hub is inefficient and impractical. I've found they run on less power and therefore transfer much slower. The chances it can crash increase. I run a health check on all of my HDs at least every 3 to 6 months depending on who often I use them. After plugging it into the PC itself, the transfer rates increase. I'm sure the quality and brand of USB hub also affect how well it work.IMO, 2TB should be the standard as far as external storage is concerned.
title: Transfer speeds vary but....

author: Conspicuous Consumer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2020
review_content: I wrote my first review stating that I could not partition this drive.  When trying to partition a second drive, I discovered my mistake.  By default, my computer choose the scheme Master Boot Record when formatting, disabling the ability to partition.  When I formatted a second time and chose Guid Partition Map, I was able to partition.  Seagate, your technician should have mentioned this when we troubleshot the problem.Initial ReviewI partition 2TB hard drives into two sections: one for Time Machine and one for manual backups (multimedia).  Every three years I retire the hard drive and start a new one so I have backups for over a decade and I have reliable hard drives. All of my non-multimedia data is backed up to iCloud and Dropbox.I'm confident that the vast majority of these drives work perfectly but I couldn't partition mine.  I tried two methods, two formats, two different OS computers and one Windows computer.  I swapped out the cable and how it connected to the computer.  There was no signs of damage to the box or to the hard drive.  I reinstalled NTFS for Mac, per Seagate's recommendations.  I chatted for 15 minutes with Seagate before we both decided to return the hard drive.  I'll go back to Silicon Power for the replacement.
title: My Bad - Use Guid Partition Map

author: kamicokrolock
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2020
review_content: So it was high time I bite the bullet and get one of these and stop relying on a million flash drives and the cloud to back up all my files. I like having redundancies, so I won't be clearing out the flash drives any time soon, but this puts my mind at ease that my documents are safe in yet another place. The drive works as it should and I've had no issues storing or transferring files from one machine to another. There was one hiccup: The drive must be formatted before you can use it and the pre loaded files that should walk you through that process were not compatible with my device. I was, however setting it up on a Macbook Pro running Sierra, so that's more on me than the manufacturer. If you are using a more recent OS, I would assume you would be less likely to encounter this same issue. It wasn't too much of an inconvenience, because you can format the drive yourself using Disk Utility. I just had to google which format I wanted it configured in and it took just a few min. The storage should be more than adequate for my needs as I m using MAYBE an eighth of it to store all my files, which includes lots of video and music files.
title: just what I needed.

author: Aaron
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2019
review_content: A handful of reviews talk about this thing going out early on but ive had mine since october of 2018. Ive filled it to the brim and also keep it connected to the laptop and use it to watch things from it daily. I use and access this thing and sometimes have it copying 50+ gigs at a time to it taking over 30 minutes at times. Ive definatly put this thing through its paces. If it was going to go out on me it would have by now from any defect. I expect nothing but smooth sailing from here but if it crashes on me anytime in the next 5 years lol ill be sure to let you know. Update : 6/16/2020.  Still running and taking lots of copying and deleting and constant watching from the drive. I watch up to 2 to 6 hours a day off this drive for the last couple years. Keep it from hard vibrations and in a nice safe permanent connected space and forget its an external. I view it as internal now.
title: So far so good!

author: MrTechieGuy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2019
review_content: I bought two of these units. The first time I tried one, a strange thing happened that I've never experienced before with a portable hard disk.I kicked off a copy of three large and complex file tree structures from the hard disk on my PC to the portable hard disk. These structures were each about 12 GB and about 35,000 files. I monitored the beginning of the copying process, and everything was proceeding normally. The copy was partially complete when I headed off to bed.The next morning, the portable hard disk was empty! More precisely, none of the files that I had started copying the night before were on the portable disk, even though I had observed that some of them had been successfully copied to the portable disk the night before.I then re-started the copying job. It succeeded on this second attempt.Since that initial problem, about two months ago, both portable hard disks have been working fine. In other words, things now seem OK, as I say in my headline. But I can't give this product five stars because of the weird day-1 behavior.
title: Seems OK

author: Joshua S. Chap
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2020
review_content: So this Hard Drive has a massive flaw, the USB that is included with this drive with it is extremely cheap and will often disconnect the Hard Drive if there is large amounts of data being transferred. I bought a new cable fixed this problem completely and  even runs faster than before when I was using the cable that was included. I highly recommend buying a USB 3.0 A Male to Micro B Cable with your order if you decide to buy this drive.
title: A solid Hard Dive with a poor cheap cable included.

author: Pigs_Fly
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2020
review_content: My only complaint would be how long it takes to be recognized by my PCs.  With either my desktop or laptop, it takes a minute and sometimes longer to recognize and populate.  Sometimes the PC doesn't recognise it at all and and I have to unplug and reconnect the drive to my USB port. I have not have issues with other brands of drives, but they are only 2TB or smaller and that may be the issues.  It might be a drive size issue with Windows 10 or issue with power supplied by the USB ports.  I use newer USB 3.0 ports on the PC, and the DVD player is 10 years old, and has a first generation USB 2 port when they came out.  The DVD player will recognise and populate the data in 20-25 seconds at the most.  May not be any issue to someone else, but when you plug it into a USB and wait 2 minutes, unplug and plug back in, and have to wait another 1-2 minutes for it to finally be recognized it can be an issue.  I have a gaming rig with all SSD drives and M.2 cards so nothing should take that long.  Like I said, it might be an issue with Windows OS, so take this with a grain of salt.  It does work fantastic with all Samsung products.
title: Good price and works great with my Samsung TV and Samsung DVD player

author: sweet teas
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2020
review_content: I don't know if this will help other buyers but...I bought this for the great price and supposed ease of use with a mac. Unfortunately, my mac never "saw" it. I tried looking for it manually and all sorts of other things, but ended up returning it for a La Cie which is Mac-optimized and gets recognized instantly by Time Machine.Before returning, I contacted Amazon tech support to get some pointers. They could not help. So, either I got a dud, or this particular drive is Mac-incompatible, at least without hassles. If you have a mac,  I would suggest that you save your time and get a La Cie instead.
title: Just didn't work with my mac

author: Mark Allan Riester II
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2020
review_content: I bought this in May of this year (2020) for my PS4, worked great and I was happy for about 4 months.My power fliped due to a bad storm. I have my systems and everything on surge protectors etc so everything but this was fine.Ever since then my PS4 or my PC won't recognize it even exist, I called Seagate customer support and after two hours of them fiddling around with it on remote-control desktop I was told that it would cost me a service charge of $200 so they could pay a tech to fix it.I told them I both didn't pay that much to buy it and that nothing I had on it was worth that.6/10 while it worked0/10 for Seagate customer support, it not lasting even a year and Seagate Not being honest and trying to trick me into that service charge, I had to ask specifically why and what the charge was and they beat around the bush before telling me; going on about "It's just a small service charge".Still haven't got it fixed.
title: Wasn't worth it.

author: Ian
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2020
review_content: After seeing the reviews, I thought this drive would work excellently as a “master backup” for all the data I owned.  Documents, media, all sorts of stuff I’ve carried over the years in one location as a fail safe.  (This was to tide me over until I purchased a NAS of similar sizes for better storage accessibility).  Well, about a week in and it turns out that all my data is gone.  Unplugged from one computer, put into the next, and the drive was blank.  I’m trying some “recovery tools” now but I don’t have high hopes.  Perhaps I got the “dud” of the manufacturing group, but I certainly can’t recommend the drive after this experience.  Slow data speeds, I’m fine with for such a large drive.  But full data erasure in a matter of seconds?  Well, that’s a bit of a problem.  Thank goodness for other backups I had, but I still lost several weeks of work from this drive failure.  I think your documents would be stored more safely in a paper shredder, but your mileage may vary.
title: Self Destruct Mode Activated

author: Brian T. Naylor
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2019
review_content: I feel like I should have payed more attention to the negative reviews. Brand new, out of the box, my computer would not recognize this drive. I tried every port with several different cables. Since I couldn't use it with my computer, I went out on a limb and connected it to my PS4. Surprisingly, it connected right away and let me format the drive to use as extended storage. I had been using a couple of 2 TB portable drives for my games. I decided since it was working on the PS4 that I would leave it connected and download my entire library of games. This turned out to be a huge mistake. It took several days to get around 7 TB of games downloaded, but the real trouble started after that. I started randomly getting error messages that the drive stopped working and needed to be repaired before continuing use. Then finally I got the dreaded message that drive can not be repaired and needs to be reformatted. All I got in the end was over a hundred dollars thrown away, days wasted downloading, and terabytes of data lost.
title: not recognized out of the box and crashes constantly

author: Bill M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2019
review_content: The capacity should have been perfect for my needs. I started populating the 4TB drive with all my stuff until I encountered some errors while writing on it. I did a surface scan using SeaTools utility and found the hard drive failing on some tests. Geez, the drive was purchased only a month ago and I got the item delivered a week after that!Anyway, I've contacted Seagate and said if there really is a problem with the drive they will replace it under warranty. I know they'll replace it. It's just the hassle I'm upset about.Now waiting for further instructions from Seagate about when I can ship the drive back for replacement.
title: Was expecting not to have problems with the drive off the bat.

author: M. Vanstone
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2020
review_content: Bought this 4TB unit for routine system backups and wanted a small portable unit that is self powered. Previously I had purchased 2TB WD Passports - and these were good and all, but this unit offered a price/performance improvement that I wanted to try.This unit proved to perform satisfactorily being powered by a single short USB3 interface cable. The size and weight are similar to the WD units (about 4" x 3" x 0.75") and fit nicely in the Amazon basics HDD carry cases.The only downside with this unit is the data transfer rate, in particular bulk write. While it seems to have a fast transfer cache, bulk writing takes a long time. For me this is not a deal breaker as I can wait for backup (for my case it took about 10 days continuously running to transfer 4TB). If this is used in a more interactive environment could be something to consider.Overall I would be happy to buy this unit again for long term storage and offline usage.
title: Nice little portable hard drive for backups - very slow

author: Txgeezer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2019
review_content: I needed a new external HD to use for my Mac's Time Machine backups. The first one started to back up extremely slowly, and within hours developed the "click of death", while slowing down the operation of the whole machine. It never did back up more than a few hundred MB out of a needed 450GB initial backup. Multiple restarts, Time Machine reset (deleting the preferences file), etc. No go.Returned it (free -- thanks Amazon!) for a replacement, with the exact same Seagate HD. Everyone gets a lemon once in a while, right? This time when I connected it, Time Machine asked me if I wanted to use it for the backup, and just for kicks I checked the "Encrypt disk" option. It claimed to be encrypting the disk, but didn't get past the 2% mark after letting it run overnight. The next morning after a couple of restarts it wouldn't even power on.So enough is enough, and I returned the second one for a refund, and bought another disk that worked perfectly rithh out of the box  (Toshiba -- see my other review).Maybe it's just Time Machine -- I don't know, but I'm glad I don't have to spend any more time trying to make this basic utility work.
title: Total failure with Mac Time Machine -- twice

author: Kris
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2020
review_content: I've ordered 2 of these. The first one was for additional storage space for my xbox, and that one seems to work fine. The second one was for computer back up - this one is not okay. It shipped without any packing material, just the unpadded product box. Hard drives are fragile... the box isn't even marked fragile. It shipped USPS. I tried to use it, and the write speed ranges from 11 to 15 MB/second... a far cry from the advertised 120 MB/second maximum. It also makes a very loud clicking and a quieter rattling noise as it tries to write. The one attached to my xbox does not make that noise. So this one was probably damaged in shipping. I'm returning it - this review is one star because of the note at the top of the page, that this item ships in the product box (which has no padding). It's a good drive if you get one that isn't damaged, but shipping it like that is a good way to damage it. Be warned.Edit: Now I'm trying to delete the items that I've copied to the drive so far, before I return it. I keep getting error messages because the files are "corrupted and unreadable." The rattling is louder. This thing is definitely damaged. I reformatted and now I'm trying to overwrite it with another program, because data security. 2 days remaining.
title: Kind of a Toss Up

author: HB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2020
review_content: Photographer here.  I recently had to upgrade from a 5TB to these 8 TB for more storage (I back up all RAW images and finished images and files).  This thing is so loud it's annoying.  I couldn't believe it! The plugs are also mislabeled.  The US plugs were switched with another countries.  They were VERY similar and while it just took common sense to differentiate the two...it still made you think and could be very dangerous! Three stars because I love Seagate products and the price for the 8 TB beat competitors.
title: ...so loud...

author: San Antonio Reader
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2020
review_content: With a larger storage capacity, there is a slight wait time if you are searching the drive for a file.  There is also a one-second lag when you store a file.  My last remote hard drive (40 GB) saved files very quickly but it had far less capacity.  I had to train myself to pause for a second when I  save files.The exterior case is sturdy.  The cord detaches and can be replaced if it is ever damaged.  The cord is short and rigid.  I take the drive to work each day.  I finally found the best way to plug it into my work computer and place the drive on the top of the CPU.
title: Runs well, lots of room, a little lag

author: The Reluctant Poet
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2019
review_content: I am a video producer and storage of footage and supporting files is a constant must have.
