In the past I would grab 1TB drives and they would fill up so quickly with HD and 4k footage that I would have to turn around and buy another. With 8TB at this price I have set for a good while. Now, I only use this as a storage drive and don't work off it at all. I use my two internal SSDs to do any work on. This drive makes it easy to store completed projects to and have at the ready if I need to pull them back up and make any changes. Highly recommend.
title: So Much Storage

author: Uki
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2020
review_content: When I went to load files onto this things went fine . . . for about 10 minutes. Then I noticed it remained at 9% for the next 20 minutes. Looking a little closer I saw it showing 1kb/sec. Now, I'm no computer wiz, but I'm pretty sure it should be loading faster than that. I decided to delete what it had loaded and start again. Except when I tried to delete, I kept getting a message that an error was preventing me from deleting. What? I never saw that before ever in all my years of using a computer or flash drives of any kind. Anyways, I tried a bunch of things but could neither load any more or delete what was there. Thought that I had got that one bad apple, but I see other reviews that described the same issues. Definitely going to return this and look at another brand.
title: Doesn't work

author: LOVE TO LEARN
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2020
review_content: I believed the reviews and bought this unit, although not my brand of choice.  While the drive initially does work as it should and back ups occur as normal, although VERY slow, my drive was inaccessible after 7 months.  I keep all drives stored away in safe, cool, location in my home and all my back up drives work and I have had some of them for over 12 years.  Now, this drive is unresponsive after 7 months.  WOuldn't care so much because I just use it for back up but my old laptop just died and all my data from that laptop is stored on this drive.  7 months folks!!!!  What a waste.  After 2 days of searching online and their website for warranty, found here from another reviewer - seriously!  Try and search for this unit on their website, you will find nothing on it.  Now, I will be spending more time trying to contact these people to get another unit or repair but that does nothing for the data I have and need that is/was stored on this drive.
title: Don't do it!!!

author: Oliver
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2020
review_content: I use them instead of a raid gig I had in the past. I just take 2 of them, backup everything on one while the other is offline and away. 8 TB for now is quite adequate and works also for larger video footage backup. The drive is also quiet. I like the simplicity of a relatively large backup solution. My raid gig needed several drives and when the controller died, I had been stranded. I might in the future get more of them also for long term backups which are not over written. These drives of course need power, unlike the smaller USB drives one can buy. But they seem also to be more reliable. The USB powered small drives usually fail after a while.
title: good quality and affordable

author: Cary Alburn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2019
review_content: I bought this 1 terabyte hard drive to convert my new Dish Wally receiver to a DVR, for satellite TV for my camper van. It arrived properly packed, but without any instructions except some graphics showing to plug it into a computer USB slot. For the average computer nerd, maybe that's adequate. For computer dummies like me, that's not. But that's the only reason for knocking down my rating to 4 stars. As soon as I plugged it in, my TV hooked to my Wally indicated that I had done so, but that was it. I had no idea what to do next.I had to call Dish per their instructions to indicate that I had it attached, but I was surprised at the service associated with that call. The extremely helpful tech support guy at Dish walked me through the entire set-up, step by step, and within about 20 minutes, it was up and running.A couple of neat things about it. First, it's powered from the Wally through the USB cable, so no external power supply is necessary. That's really handy for installation in my camper van's cabinetry; although I have 120v power available, that made for a neater, less bulky installation. The USB cable that came with it is short, but long enough that it fit my installation perfectly.Second, it's very compact. Again that made it handy for installation in my camper van's cabinetry, because it takes up next to no room in the A/V cabinet, tucked over to the side. Space in any camper van is at a premium, and I'm still able to store everything in the A/V cabinet that I had previously, because of the compact size of this hard drive.As I use this, I'll get a better handle on how well it works, and if anything happens that cause me to revisit this review, I'll amend it.
title: Easy to install to my Wally Dish receiver, with tech help from Dish

author: Darryl Hartsoe Jr
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2020
review_content: 10 Terrabytes for $165, haha suckers I got a steal.....oh wait, it stopped working after less than a week, whos the sucker now...I am.If I was to catch Covid and Seagate was the last brand to make ventilators I wouldn't buy from them even if they applied this payment to the cost of said imaginary ventilator, even if said ventilator was covered by my insurance and I got it free I'd rather take my chances with Jesus on the main line, I'd just tell him what I want.The first night was very promising, everything ran smooth, now "the purchase" sounds like an XBox 360 that is experiencing the red ring of death, it makes clicking and whirring noises and it freezes my mouse so that I have to use the built in mousepad on my laptop, I am just waiting for this thing to transform into a decepticon so I can throw some water on it.As long as I have it plugged in and do not try to access it everything looks fine, open files and folder and I see it sitting there but click on it in an attempt to access my stored data and my computer tells me its "working on it", like it literally says its "working on it" of course this period of calm is all after the initial red ring of death/clicking/whirring/decepticon phase.That being said if anybody takes a shot on this one, good luck to you....dummy
title: This idiot thought he was getting a deal!!!!

author: wesley maynard
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2020
review_content: I purchased the 10tb external drive for $168. It was immediately recognized. The total formatted size is 9.09tb. plugged into USB3 I ran it through a speed test and it averaged a solid 230MBps. I expected this to be a 5400 RPM drive but with these read and write speeds it seemed like this was a 7200 RPM drive.So I cracked open the case to see exactly what kind of drive was inside. This one has a Seagate Ironwolf NAS 7200 RPM ST10000NE0008. It is rated to max out at 240MBps and I'm getting right up to the max performance.So far I am not having any noise issues.
title: 10tb drive is 7200rpm and fast

author: H. Ho
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2020
review_content: I mistakenly opened the hard drive after 1 month of it sitting there.  It was NEVER dropped or mishandled.  I plugged it in and it started to spin and rattle.  It is very loud and it does not even vibrate evenly.  It sounds like it will eventually crash, as I had many hard drives crash on me.  I fear adding any more data on it as it will crash and I will lose a significant amount of data.  I cannot return it to Amazon because it has been over 1 month with Amazon.  With Seagate support, I have a mail in the drive back, which I don't mind.  But now I have to buy another drive to back my information in the meal time.  This drive is loud as it is constantly reminding me that it is spinning and unevenly spinning, thus it rattles.  Avoid if you can.
title: Rattles, vibrates and is loud

author: Clown Prince
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2020
review_content: My portable HDD all of a sudden is making a buzzing noise nonstop until I pick it up and give it a very light tap.  Don't know what is causing it but it's really annoying.  There was small electronic clicking noise and that has stopped for a few days and the buzzing started to happen.  My other Seagate which I had for over 5 years now does not make a sound.
title: Starting to make a noise

author: Prometheus A.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2020
review_content: This enclosure contains a Barracuda drive with SMR technology; Meaning it is slow for sequential and random writes of any size. However, if you setup multiple transfers at a time it will write to separate platters, allowing for you to hit a higher transfer rate at the cost of disk responsiveness.Raw test scores had this drive sitting at 130 MB/s Read, 21 MB/s WriteWhen roughly 11 windows file transfers were started at once, it managed to sustain a 70 MB/s transfer rate, slowing only when several small files were being written (only slowing writes to that target platter without affecting other streams).It comes with multiple adapters for power, so it is an international drive.The casing is plastic, low grade, and very sharp.From other reviews on DataHoarders, this drive is shuckable, so you can use it as internal storage, however, this will void warranty. The low price comes from slow writes in real world operation and high device failure rate. WD EasyStores are still recommended.Last, but not least, NEVER format to ReFS.
title: Decent Archive Disk When MultiStreamed

author: Cindy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2020
review_content: I was specifically looking for a hard drive that came already formatted, for a MacBook Pro because I am very untechie. I also wanted it to automatically back up my most up to date files, when plugged in.  I plugged it in every day, thinking I was backing up my business files. A message popped up, on my laptop that my files had not been backed up in 14 days. Several of those days were while waiting for the drive to arrive but a call to Seagate, as to why it wasn't just backing files up,  was confusing and I was going to return it. Luckily a family member knew how to format it and set it so that it would backup automatically and with the most recent information. It had to be coordinated with time clock (something new to me). He said it was easy, but if you are a low tech person, with no high tech friends, this may frustrate you. Otherwise it is a nice little unit, and the carry case is hard sided and nice.
title: This is not a plug and go. You must format it to work for a Mac and to automatically back up.

author: Archie A. Chipps
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2020
review_content: I have a hard time trusting drive since I lost over 8 years of digital art. Book drives die from being shook, and other drives locking up when dropped and not being used at the time. I know it would lock up the drive if it was running, and then there was those Western Digital internal drives with green, blue, and black that can't write everything programs used, Like Poser had files missing that the drive should have written to the drives, but I guess it didn't understand the language or something. I just know that program will not run on Caviler Blue. I had to replace that drive when it was still new with no support with the problem, because the people had no clue what the problem was.I bough my first Seagate portable drive, and you can hear it was stiff, and needed to loosen up, or die in a short time, and then it loosened up after it was used for a year. Since then other new drives made by Seagate just work normally with no problems. I was showing someone the drive when it slipped out of my hand and dented the corner. I still use that drive. It is nice that these are being sold cheaper than other drives while it seems to be the better drives. So my only disappointment was after I bought this 4 terabyte drive they came out with a 5 terabyte drive at the same price.
title: I made this my most used drive

author: Chris
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2020
review_content: Update: I managed to use chkdsk to recover some of the files. I discovered that inside is the notoriously bad rosewood ST2000LM007 drive. Google "ST2000LM007 reliability", these drives are known to fail w/out warning. Seagate's "Enjoy long term peace of mind with the included 1 year limited warranty" advertisement should have been a red flag. 1 year is "long term"? What a joke from their marketing department. But 1 year is as long as they want to take responsibility for it, so that should tell you something. Don't use this for irreplaceable backups and/or as primary storage.Original review:Never had a drive fail like this, should have paid more attention to the negative reviews, but instead trusted Seagate's past reputation and previous experience. I purchased in Aug '19 and copied some data for backup purposes. I recently made a back up of one of my computers, and did the same for another today. I went to copy a few more things back and forth today and the drive failed with Win10 telling me "drive corrupted, can't read it". Properties show 0 bytes capacity and 0 used. Some of my data was temporarily only on this drive so there's a good chance that's gone forever.This product deserves zero stars. Seagate does not cover data recovery in their warranty - they should for drives that fail so quickly.One other thing - the case feels cheap. It's in a flimsy plastic case and has no rubber feet to keep it from sliding around.
title: Files gone after half a dozen or so uses - this uses the infamous rosewood ST2000LM007 drive

author: Conrad Nelson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2019
review_content: I pulled the drive out of this and it worked fine inside my media server (it was the cheapest 8TB drive available). Works great, and still going a couple months later.
title: Shucked and used for a media server

author: RyeBri
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2020
review_content: The hard drive works just as expected and transfers everything quickly, as fast as you would expect from a usb.The hard drive is light and a nice size. Can easily be stored away but also probably easily lost. Especially the cord. I have so many 6” length usb cords now for different things, like the charger for the doorbell ring. Would have been nice to have it attached. It’s not a standard usb outlet into the hard drive, soYou can’t use every usb cable around.The drive also starts out with all the service info and warranty info ON the hard drive. So for someone who isn’t very experienced or if you happen to need it. It may cause an issue if you can’t get to it. But what are you really going to do.Overall it works wel for the price. Got 1t onBlack Friday for 60. If you can wait, maybe it will come back.
title: Works great, small, and light

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2019
review_content: Considering that it's a standard 2.5-inch mechanical hard drive the Read Write speeds are okay when using a USB 3.0 port. Lots of room, inexpensive. If you are trying to save edited video, you might want to fork out the extra cash for one that's an SSD. One odd thing and this most likely has nothing to do with this drive, but it won't work when plugged into my front USB 3.0 port on my desktop computer, but my front USB port works just fine with all other USB 3.0  devices. The drive works just fine in my rear USB 3.0 ports and it works in the front USB 3.0 port of another desktop that I have that has the same MB and CPU. My front USB 3.0 is in a Zalman T1 case.My 2TB Seagate drive died on April 11, 2019. So it worked fine for about 2 1/2 months, then died. It just totally went dead and quit working with no warning. Fortunately, I have backups for the data I had stored on it (actually, it was the backup). I had to pay about $8 postage to return the drive to Seagate and they shipped me another new drive (refurb) that I got today. The replacement drive is working okay at this time.
title: Read Write speeds are okay for what it is. Updated

author: Bill G.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2019
review_content: I have bought these in the past, plugged them into the computer, and they install and work fine. This external hard drive was extremely difficult to use. Upon plugging it into the computer, it would be recognized, drivers would install, but it was nowhere to be found as a usable drive. Happened on 3 different computers.Only after extensive googling was I able to go through the drive manager, format, and assign a drive letter, was this usable. None of this was in the included instructions. Works fine now, but will not get another one after the hours of frustration that this caused.
title: Not usable out of the box

author: Sandy (WA)
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2020
review_content: My 8TB drives were fine until they got more than half full. Writes became so slow I had to do all my work on other drives and schedule a time to transfer results to the big drives. It would take forever as the drives thrashed trying to re-shingle data. Terrible performance. And then I started getting corrupted files, so I had to dump these things and replace with CMR drives. It's fine if you only need half the drive's capacity, but who buys a large drive for half its capacity? Avoid SMR technology. Seagate should be ashamed of themselves for not revealing that this is an SMR product.
title: Avoid SMR Drives

author: Dio
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2020
review_content: This is a brand new drive. Loaded all my photos and videos from the last 20 years on it and day or two later,. Boom I/O errors.! Freaking paperweight!  I can care less about the drive.  The info lost was worth it's weight in gold.  Chatted with customer service and they offered a 15 buck discount?!!  Keep your money! Don't buy from these clowns unless you want slow writing speeds and or lost data!  JOKE!!!!!!!!!  144 bucks out the damn window. Seriously, there should be as law against crap like this.  DO NOT BUY THIS POS DRIVE!!!!!!!!!
title: OMG you ripped me off and lost all my data? You suck!

author: HKN
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2018
review_content: This drive is either refurbished or the quality is very poor. It failed the first time and then technical support asked me to format it - I did that - it still does not work properly. When you are trying to backup data - you don't want a drive that is unreliable to begin with. Buy another vendor/product that is available. Stay away from this one.
title: Stay away from this drive. This drive failed and did not even work the first time properly

author: A Ester
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2020
review_content: Unbelievably unreliable. Currently transferring 3 terrabytes to western digital drive that worked and connected perfect out of the box with no problem. I thought these were the same company. So I bought 2 of these first one worked fine for a month, but then wouldn't allow writing to disk and could only move things off. Almost gave up, but the 8th time I started up to move things off, returned to normal.Second one I bought, the power randomly shut off  every  30 min(my current WD plugged into the exact place that was connected to the same port w/o a problem)Anyway, not reliable, buyer beware.
title: 1st one courrupted , 2nd one power failure

author: Nelbert
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2020
review_content: I'm so old that I remember spending nearly $1000 for a 1Gb HD and being thrilled to have gotten so much disk space for so little. This drive is 5000X that for barely over $100. For an external, the drive is fast, and Seagate's reputation for quality is well earned.I was also amazed at the speed of delivery: same day!
title: Yuge!

author: Steven Podvoll
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2020
review_content: I was using this HD as a Time Machine backup. Within about 6 months it started unmounting itself in the middle of backing up for no reason.Thankfully, I also kept a secondary backup on a Western Digital portable drive.  So, I tried reformatting the Seagate at which point it would not unmount for a proper erasure and reformat.  I ended up trying to reformat it using 2 other computers and multiple system formats (APFS, OSX extended, even MSDOS FAT) to no avail.  It's about as useful as a doorstop or a hockey puck now.  I should have known better than to trust Shugart (Seagate) products.So, now I'm figuring out which Western Digital model I want to use as my main Time Machine backup.  The Seagate is still under warranty but there's no way I will trust my backups to a replacement unit.  I might as well have flushed my money down the toilet.
title: interface failed after less than a year

author: Patrick
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2019
review_content: I actually bought this drive to remove it from the case (easy enough but voids the warranty) and use it in conjunction with a 500 GB SSD to create a fusion drive in my 2011 MacBook Pro. This drive works a treat! Very quiet and a ton of space. As a main drive this 5400 RPM drive would be very slow, but as a storage drive for large files its hard to beat. And I got to keep the USB case to house an older, smaller drive to boot! Color me happy!
title: Tons of storage and super quiet at a very nice price.

author: Forrest E Hodge
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2019
review_content: This a compact 1TB external HDD.  It benchmarks quite well for a mechanical HDD, particularly a 2.5 inch inch mechanical HDD.  However it's real-world performance isn't exactly amazing. Transferring large video files (around 2-3GB each, about 100GB total) yielded a write speed of around 17-22 MB/sec, well under the 130~ MB/sec it benched at.  The source drive is a 1TB NVMe SSD.Overall it's fine for the price, it's light and has a small form factor, it's just not very fast in real world use, and the USB 3.0 cable it comes with is quite short, maybe a foot long.
title: Works okay, but real world speeds don't match benchmarks

author: Sam
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2020
review_content: I like the slick look of the hard drive. It has a really nice look and is thin! I don't know if I would recommend this specific hard drive to a friend though because there is a strange sequel noise when I pull it out of my USB port (I of course eject the drive and wait for a minute, too). It is really concerning, honestly. I'm scared to back-up important media on it without having it backed up to another place. I've had a great experience with WD and may be going with them next, though I own this Seagate 2TB and a Seagate 5TB. They're just solid.
title: One of the lightest harddrives out there, but concerning noise when unplugging USB

author: TazandSteve
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2020
review_content: I have an OG XBOXONE with a 500g drive which means like 3 games at any given time. I got this so I could have some selection and not get capacity anxiety. Once hooked up, the Xbox sees it, asks you how you want to use it, and then has it ready within minutes. I set this as my preferred installation location and have all my games on it.Recently I got a second Xbox one. The coolest thing is that I can simply plug this into whichever box I'm using (one in the living room and one in the bedroom) and all my games are there. No installing on each Xbox or whatever. Just swap over the drive and I'm golden.
title: Use for Xbox One

author: SaltyDog
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2020
review_content: This unit is working great for me so far. I leave it plugged into my desktop all the time. I primarily got this for a second backup to all our family personal media. I have put about 1 TB of movies on it so far and it barely looks used. I know others said these die but we will see. Since it is not my first or second relied on storage device, having another one gives me confidence that I will not lose all three at the same time. I have a 2 TB internal drive, a high impact SSD 2TB external drive and now this one. I also have Carbonite but recently found out that the basic service only saves the first 4GB of storage per file. So all this time, my home movies which are double that capacity per file were clipped off without me knowing. So if you rely on Carbonite, you either have to pay a ;mint to have them store everything or just get one of these 8TB drives to do the trick.
title: Soooooo Biggggg

author: Wayne Freeman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2020
review_content: NOT DESIGNED TO LAST!!This isn't even a full 4 months old (5TB model) and it started failing a few weeks back.  A few days ago it wouldn't initialize at all.  The standard windows disk management showed as raw un-formatted drive.  chkdsk couldn't access the drive at all in windows.When I checked the drive with Ontrack it showed both 4.55TB Linux and 4.55TB NTFS partitions available to be scanned for data recovery.  Capacity showed 1.89TB free space and more than a terabyte of bad blocks/sectors in disk diagnostic scan.Upon system boot from powered off state (not the first time powered off and on just the first that it checked the drive)  the chkdsk recovered the contents of drive but didn't do it correctly as the restore previous versions of the folders were not accessible nor could I get into the folder found.000 as it was locked by a weird owner name that I later found out was a hidden folder in the $recyclebin folder.  Or at least had the same name.  I changed the access privileges and now  I'm in the process of recovering my 2.6+TB of data.  Hopefully I can get it all back but I highly doubt it.
title: Failing  After just 4 months

author: Donna T.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2020
review_content: I bought the  4TB Seagate Portable External Hard Drive hoping to use it for storing backups and copies of often used data.  My Windows 10 system immediately recognized it and I started a 39GB copy from my hard drive.  It indicated a 2hr. 5min transfer time... I let it continue.  Typically windows displays the transfer time which changes as the copy proceeds.. at one point it it displayed a 50min transfer time but it never got any better.I then noted the actual transfer rate which varied between 7MB/Sec to the fastest which was 20MB/sec. which best case works out to 32min to transfer 39MB.  I then plugged in a Samsung 64GB flash drive followed by a 5 yr.  old Western Digital 3TB MyBook and did the same copy... Both of which maintained an average transfer rate of 50GB - 80GB/sec....  A 3 to 4 times improvement.  Bottom line:  This is a good little drive for occasional storage but be prepared for long waits on big transfers.  I had to return it and get a more speedy drive.
title: Inadequate Transfer Speed

author: MRG818
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2020
review_content: I bought those as a backup for all of my graphic design files. I needed to clear out some room on my laptop. It just completely stopped working one day after only having it for two months. Lost over 10,000 graphic design files, including files that I CREATED that cannot be replaced. Customer service offered to send a new one; but I can’t really use it seeing as it’s not reliable. They also offered to TRY to recover my files. I am still waiting for my replacement to arrive, and it will take over 30 days once they have third one to even try to recover any files. So much time and money that I could never get back.. 6 months of work gone forever. DO NOT BUY THIS!
title: DIED AFTER 2 MONTHS- LOST EVERYTHING!

author: Vincent M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2020
review_content: Used for less than a month, loaded the hard drive with priceless videos and photos. When I tried creating a new folder within the drive, it completely crashed the computer. Spent 3 painstaking days of trouble shootsing. Now it no longer is able to read the device, and now I have to spend $400 up to $1000 for data recovery service. Contacted Seagate to see if anything can be done with Warranty. Since the data recovery service needs to access the enclosure to retrieve the data, that voids the warranty. Now I'm out the $100 I payed for the drive, plus another $400-$100 I have to spend on data recovery, and THEN another $200 for a better WD hard drive that would be way more reliable than this Seagate drive.  Very bad experience, was hoping it wouldn't happen to me like the fraction of the reviews here on Amazon, but I guess I was one the unlucky ones. My advice, stick with Western Digital.
title: Failed within 1 month of use

author: Efrain V.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2018
review_content: I had bought this hard drive alone with the backup plus. To transfer 534gb if games in my PS4 pro it took 130 minutes to complete. With the backup plus it took 96 minutes. I will miss the extra 3tb of space that this one has provided. But 10tb on a ps4 pro was overkill to begin with. 7tb is enough.
title: Fast but not fast enough.

author: Roger B
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2020
review_content: Whenever I get a new drive, I run a copy test to determine if the drive is operating correctly.  I firs use DISKPART to remove any existing partitions, then create a single partition and format.  My copy test is a robocopy of approximately 3TB of video MKV files from my Plex server.  After all, I use the drives to back up my Plex server.The robocopy command is:robocopy <source dir> <dest dir> dcopy:dt /s /w:1 /r:1 /np /fp /ndl /njh /tee /z /mirI monitor the write data rate between two usb3 connections or across my 1 Gbit LAN back bone.Drives should easily perform at a write rate of at least 50 MB/s continuously as the file sizes are all between 1 GB and 15GB.This drive started out at 2.2 MB/s and never increased.  After 5 minutes I shut down the copy, erased and returned the drive to Amazon.  I do get bad drives, but they usually start out okay and then die.  This one was crap from the start.
title: Very poor write performance at 2.2 MB/s. - returned

author: Stewart N. Grant
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2019
review_content: I wanted to use this review to address some of the other reviews1) The drive is "noisy" -  I do not find this drive to be noisy compared to other drives.2) "Write times are slow or unacceptable" - I transferred 2.5TB of video files using robocopy from one usb 3.0 drive to this usb 3.0 drive and it averaged just above 200gb per hour.  I don't know if that is "fast" but it is a lot faster than folks are claiming in other reviews.3) "lost data"  - I truly don't understand folks complaining about lost data these days with terabytes of storage being so inexpensive.  Every drive I have is backed up and/or mirrored to another drive because I know that every drive will eventually fail and many times without warning despite smart technology.  If you have important data, buy more than one of these drives and save yourself a lot of grief.This is my 3rd of these drives.  One is about 5 years old and the other slightly older (still working great) and I am very pleased with them and as my need for storage and backup grows, I fully expect to buy more.
title: Nice drive with plenty of storage

author: Comdet
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2019
review_content: I'm pleased with this external drive. It's 100% plug-and-play -- zero effort needed to get it operational. It comes NTFS formatted, which is perfect for my needs. The included cable is short but decently sturdy.  Other pluses include an operational light that is easy to see but not distracting and a reasonably compact size.  Operational speed has been more than acceptable on both USB 2.0 and 3.0 ports. I didn't track the specific transfer rate, but it performed as well if not better than other USB drives I have.The only notable negative is the case. It's plastic, as expected, but rather flimsy feeling. This is not a drive that will withstand any measure of being knocked around.  An SSD drive would be a better choice if durability is the goal.This suits my needs perfectly as a very affordable, basic, everyday backup drive that will rarely leave the office. 4.5 stars (due to the plastic case which could have been better) but I'll round up to 5 since it does everything else very well at a reasonable price.
title: Good performance and value for the price

author: kkrome25
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2019
review_content: I'm a photographer, and I don't need to complicate my work flow. This Seagate 8 TB EHD is truly is a plug-in-and-store type of drive. No setup needed. It's like a gigantic thumb drive.  I'm using it to store TIFF, DNG/RAW, AVCHD, MPEGS and JPEGS. Every 3 to 5 years, technology improves. Storage capacity gets bigger, and the prices become more affordable and that's good for us. So far, so good (great). No problems at all. I was led to think it was small, but it's not. It's 7 inches long, 4.6 inches wide, and 1.6 inches thick. You can call it portable, but I think not. In the not-too-distant future, we will see DNA drive, and 100 TB in a thumb drive.
title: So Far, So Great

author: A. Tang
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2020
review_content: Great drive. I use this for backing up old raw video files and photos that I don't plan on editing or using.I format the drive to exfat and added bitlocker encryption to it on Windows 10. Everything is working fine. Sometimes you get very slow transfer speed 10mbs. And sometimes it's fast 100mbs.After waiting an hour to backup 66gb of videos (10mbs speed) I unmounted the drive and replug it. I copied 88gb of videos into a different folder and the speed went up to 149mb/s. Only took 11minutes. Very unusual behaviorI recommend that you organize your files into smaller 60-80gb sections and copy them over individually to see how the speed changes. Don't copy over a giant 1tb portion all at once. That might oveheat
title: Sometimes fast, sometimes slow

author: Mo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2020
review_content: As you can see in the pictures mentioned, the speed for my 5TB external drive is suitable. Suitable means I am using it for personal usage, not office purposes, also I have enough time to transfer data, so the speed is excellent for personal or privet users. On the other hand, random transferring data (including pic/video/word file, etc.,.) is shown in the second pic, which is very good for personal and even office users. The computer was used for these tests was MAC. You might have different results on other software or systems.after reviewing a lot of external hard drives, I realized that:1- spending money on just one target, such as "anti-shake," is good but cannot guaranty your target of purchasing the drive. Buy the best carrying case instead of.2- I tried several times to shake the drive, format, remove the data, etc., just to make sure this particular item that I ordered works well, and then I started storing my essential data on it. Some reviews were telling the stories of remove data; that's why I test it in 30 days to make sure it works well. Good luck with your purchase.
title: Good product

author: Gordon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2020
review_content: I spent over 1.5 hours with Tech support. I downloaded their program to test it. The quick test said ok. They then said I needed to run the deep test and email screenshot of the result.  The test ran over 12 hours. The result said failed. I actually had to run it twice because the 1st time computer went to sleep. They also are a contact for other well-known brands.  The cost was less than $100. Why did not just say send it back and we will send you a replacement. I must have at least 5 hours in a plug and play device.
title: Very slow writes speed and worthless Tech support

author: R. Hunt
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2020
review_content: For years and years I've been carrying around a 500gb drive with archives of things I don't want to lose -- mostly photos and videos.  The old drive was very large and bulky, slower than modern drives, and required not only a USB cable to connect to the computer but also a separate wall-wart brick power supply.  For sake of a more compact lifestyle I decided I wanted something smaller and more convenient, and more storage.This drive doubled my storage, while coming in at less than ¼ of the size of my old drive. It is significantly faster. And it is capable of drawing its power from the same USB connection that transfers data... so I no longer have a big mess of cords and wall warts.  I am thoroughly happy with this.
title: Exactly what I needed

author: Matt @ LookIntoHawaiiDotCom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2019
review_content: I'm a huge fan of these for backup drives. Small, cheap, portable. I can buy two and have redundant backups in case one fails and it doesn't cost and arm and a leg. They're super quiet (no noise at all really) and don't vibrate like some drives. They also do NOT require external power, just the included USB cable (which is normal USB on one end but not the other so if you need a longer cable you need to buy a USB extension cable).
title: Great backup drives...

author: N. D. Gumby
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2019
review_content: The drive formats and works on Linux. Unlike some other external drives I've tried, it doesn't automatically disconnect after inactivity, which is good. However, when writing large amounts of data, the drive can't multitask. If you even try to "cd" into the drive and "ls" some files while it's writing lots of files, your command might hang for 30 seconds. That doesn't happen with my internal drives, nor with previous externals I've owned. Perhaps there's some way to configure the drive so the lag doesn't happen, but out of the box, it does.UPDATE: I have now purchased 4 of these drives, and 2 were defective. One of them reported thousands of bad blocks, and the other was half the speed. Thank you Amazon for having such an easy return process. I won't buy any more of these drives.UPDATE 2: Another of my 4 drives started reporting disk errors. I returned it to Seagate under warranty (very easy process). They shipped me a replacement drive. After 6 months, it's reporting errors too. BAD quality.
title: Poor quality control, poor multitasking

author: Mr. C
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2020
review_content: The first unit I got was defective, but it wasn't totally obvious.  I found the drive only wrote about 20-30MB per second (and I just assumed that was because of the type of magnetic storage used - although I don't expect those to be that slow...).  It also made a lot of clicky noises (that was the first big clue).After writing a couple TB of data the OS kept remounting it read-only.  And a bad block/sector scan found several.This device shipped with a lot of bad blocks.The replacement has been great so far.  No rapid clicky noises, and it's writing around 100MB per second.  So it's a 5 star drive (it is what it claims to be), but plan to do a return and check the drive before using it..
title: Defective unit issues

author: Mad
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2020
review_content: The drive came in and it seemed to be fine, a bit dusty and not in the original packaging. The instructions also seemed to be a bit dated making it very difficult to reformat the drive to the newest MAC OS system. That was the worst part, reformatting took forever, two computers and two people to figure it out since it would just not work. Finally it was able to work on both PC and MAC without issue so far.Files don’t take to long to drag and drop and I am using this for a 3tb photo/video archive that has grown to big for my current drive. It is definitely slower than my LaCie but a good alternative for a backup when you need more space. Decently portable, only take it when you absolutely need to and it wouldn’t be too much of a hassle.Overall it has been good but I will update this if anything happens.
title: Pretty Good

author: E
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2020
review_content: I bought this drive as a substitute for a Seagate drive that was dropped and failed.  I paid a data recovery firm to transfer the recovered data to this drive. Luckily I backed it up immediately because this drive stopped functioning as it sat on my desk. I HAD ONLY USED IT FOR 8 DAYS!!!  I'M NOT SENDING IT IN TO USE THE DATA RECOVERY SERVICE THAT CAME WITH IT AS IT ONLY HAS 8 DAYS OF INFO ON IT AND IT'S SENSITIVE INFORMATION I DON'T WANT TO BE SENT ALL OVER THE PLANET. TOTALLY PISSED!
title: NEVER AGAIN!

author: Jesus
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2020
review_content: the seagate offers a warranty that you have to pay postage for, in my case it would cost me 20 dollars to send a package to them you would need an electrostatic bag and other things JUST FOR THEM TO EVEN GIVE YOU A NEW DRIVE, at that point i'd just rather buy another hard drive i've only had this non sense for 4 months before it finally broke not mention that would occasionally disconnect every so often on it's on will, destroying my saved data on programs that were runningall my data lost thanks to seagate i feel conned out of 55 dollars that i spent on thisfurther more if you really need an external drive do not buy this one it BREAKS easily and it cost half as much just to send it to them with strict guidelines on how to send a BROKEN ITEM
title: ABSOLUTELY HORRID

author: JimV
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2020
review_content: I have a Seagate 1T drive like this 2T drive that has served me well but this drive and 4 others before it would not reformat to MacOS and work as it should if any at all at times. I worked with Seagate support using their step by step instructions to reformat which is the steps I always use to no avail.When plugging in the drive one time it might show up in utilities or it might not. When it did show up you might be able to drop a file to it and send it to trash but also you might not be able to remove the file at all and the next time you plugged in the drive the file may not be there. I got tired of messing with them so went back to my old Internal internal drives and my drive hub for backups. Very Disappointed I really like the one terabyte I have.
title: Small USB drives

author: ElwoodJD
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2020
review_content: Never experienced this before, but after my toddler flipped the switch on the power strip this drive was plugged into, I was unable to boot it ever again despite a lot of troubleshooting.  Officially it provided a Code 43 error in Windows, but no amount of re-installing drivers or other solutions worked.  On my Mac, it won't even recognize that anything is plugged into USB.  At least Windows sees it and says there is a USB device malfunction (it won't even recognize it as a harddrive, and I can't seem to reformat it).  Never had a hard drive receive hardware failure from power loss (sure, lost some data here and there), but this became an extremely expensive brick in about 6 months.  Very disappointed in the hardware quality and would highly recommend another manufacturer.  I won't be back to Seagate after this experience.
title: Failed After Losing Power Once - Only 6 Months Old

author: Brandon D. Mccain
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2020
review_content: I use this drive for both DATA AND GAMES. I have loaded over 10 games from Steam that are Heavyweights. GTA 4 / 5, Skyrim Special Edition (175 mods loaded), Arma 3, Dying Light, Division 2,  ect. Most of these games load neck-and neck with the SSD's I have in my PC. I suffer no bottle-necking. Amazing this is still a rotary drive but, SATA and USB Standards are way better than just five years ago.Ryzen 1500 (NOT overclocked)16 GB Hyperex RAM @ 1400mhzMSI Nvidia GTX 1080Aorus MOBO Gen 13 SSD Samsung 850sMost games MOVED from SSD as performance is still awesome.
title: Depending on your needs, this is a great deal and performance.

author: DG  in MA
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2020
review_content: I have been a big user and proponent of Amazon-no longer.  The last two products I've ordered from Amazon have not worked as advertised.  I've already submitted a review of the Dymo labeler that was supposed to work with Macs but nowhere does the copy indicate it does not work with Catalina.  I purchased this seagate external hard drive that states it's compatible with Macs. It downloaded about 1/3 of my pictures then I got an "Unknown Error" message stating it could not download the rest of the photos.  I called Amazon and was transferred to Seagate.  It turns out this product is made exclusively for Amazon- Amazon does not disclose this information.  Despite claims that it is  compatible with Macs it needs to be formatted to do so, there were no instructions that inform of this. Also the device cannot be located on the Seagate website. I called Amazon, was transferred to Seagate.  Over 1 hour was spent discussing my issue.  I did not want to simply return the device since it had several of my pictures on it.  Although patient, and ultimately not having to pay for a new product they were able to remove my pictures and will send me a new device, one that is made specifically for Macs.  I must send the original device back, without a refund, they are simply sending me a hopefully better replacement.  I'm furious at Amazon for their lack of transparency and the poor product description, that is likely written by the manufacturer.
title: HORRIBLE PRODUCT, misleading product information, terribly disappointed with Amazon

author: Living Beyond Life, LLC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2020
review_content: This thing's rocking on my xbox one x. Exactly what I bought it for. Still not sure if games run faster off of it or internal HD (I think they do, especially Borderlands 3 with iheartradio running in the bkg, which is awesome). Didn't rate tech support because haven't needed it yet. Plug and play, use your xbox os to reformat it (because why not, it knows what's best for it because it's using it). Highly recommend, as someone who has had countless external hard drives for the past two decades. Oh, if you don't have a usb 3.0 port but a cheaper one because you're wasting money on something that can't perform as fast with your old tech! :)  Also, not sure why storage capacity is one of the criteria for rating this, it clearly states that it's a terabyte, though is always slightly less for reasons that tech people know.
title: Delicious piece of storage capacity

author: Ed
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2019
review_content: Only had this drive (the 8TB) in use for about a month, but I have put it through its paces writing and moving numerous very large files. When connected to a USB-C port on my PC or a USB 3.0 port on my NAS, it handles everything I can throw at it.  8TB of storage is also fairly affordable these days.  I am more than comfortable with the $140 price tag given the solid performance.  If it lasts a year under these heavy loads, then a fifth star would be more than warranted.  The only disadvantage is that the drive requires a separate power supply, meaning it's not perfectly plug-and-play, but it did arrive with a full suite of global plug adapters for the power supply, which was a rare and welcome bonus.
title: Workhorse desktop storage

author: Beachbear2014
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2020
review_content: This drive is inexpensive, fast and versatile. I was amazed to find that all I had to do to use this drive, in 3 generations of operating systems, was to simply plug it in. One very old HP with Windows Pro and the first AMD duel core processor made recognized the drive and utilized it immediately. My second was a custom built 4 core Intel running Windows 7 and my third system is a quad core, 10th generation Intel laptop running Windows 10. As potentially problematic as it might have been this drive worked with all without a hiccup.  I bought it for the price and I'm going to buy another because of the quality. Seagate is out of its slump so now Western Digital has somevreal competition!
title: It's well engineered and genuinely compatible.

author: Meticode
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2019
review_content: I bought these as an upgrade to my Seagate 2TB external hard drive. That hard drive was USB 3.0 and my TCL Roku TV would detect the drive just fine so I could play my movies off of it. I bought this drive as an upgrade because I ran out of storage from of all the 4K movies I started collecting. For whatever reason the TV would NOT detect this 8TB drive initially. It wasn't the drive's fault. I went through Roku's documentation and they state that their TVs will sometimes detect 3.0 drives and sometimes not. It's kind of random and there's no way to tell if their TVs will detect certain hard drives out of the box. Most of the time to fix the issue if you plug  a USB 2.0 extension cable into the USB 3.0 cable running from the drive and plug the other end into the TV it fixes the issue. Which it did for me. Drives works perfectly fine. Seemingly Roku TVs have finicky about USB 3.0 cables since the USB port in the TV is 2.0.In the end, if you get a USB 3.0 hard drive for ANY Roku TV, I would recommend buying a USB 2.0 extension cable as well to almost guarantee that the TV would detect the drive.
title: Works for Roku TV (If you get a USB 2.0 Extension Cable)

author: Paul E. King
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2020
review_content: I got this because I need to move 5TB of backups offline (think ransomware mitigation strategy and the assumption that all data will be compromised) - maximum write speed I've sustained is just over 41 MBPS on a USB 3.1 connection with caching turned on, optimize for performance turned on, rebooting, and using teracopy.5TB will take 1.5 days, which means this drive is essentially useless for grabbing a snapshot of the current data set as I will have to copy the current data set to another drive with 5TB free, or avoid backing anything up for two days while it processes.So yeah, reads good and fast, writes slow and garbage. Don't use these for anything serious.
title: A USB 3 drive with write speeds of a USB 2 cable

author: inquisitive cat
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2020
review_content: This thing is slick. I am used to older, bulkier drives (because I am cheap) but this drive is the exact opposite. It is new tech for me (box says 2019 which is a minor gripe but in the times of COVID-19 I am just happy I got a nice new piece of tech to solve my problem).My problem was I was out of space on my xbox one and wanted a FAST and relatively spacious solution. I found this drive and being a SeaGate fan gave it a shot. It is a little bit bigger than a business card in footprint and around 1/2' thick. It is light and really quick based on my xbox playing aka "testing".This drive just set the new standard for hard drives for me. I am sure there are sleeker and smaller but this one fits my price range and needs.
title: New, sleek tech (for me)

author: Michael N.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2020
review_content: So others mileage might very but something is wrong with the one I got. From initial look at it everything it seemed all in order. But now that I have been using it for a little while I have noticed a truly irritating problem that I do not have with any of my other external drives. This one keeps randomly disconnecting from my PC and then reconnecting. Seeing as I am usually moving large files to it this is a pretty big problem as it has damaged/corrupted data as a result. I keep back ups so I have not lost anything but for someone who doesn't this could be catastrophic. This is usually a decent brand so I think it is likely that I was just unlucky and got the one buggered one to roll of the line. It happens, but still I would be weary of this one. Might be best to just get a different model, or go with another brand/manufacturer all together.
title: I think mine might be defective

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2020
review_content: Worked well for intended use. My son ran out of storage on his PlayStation and had to delete games in order to make room for more. He’s now been able to replace the games he had to delete as well as download 15-20 new ones and he has plenty more space to download future purchases. Shipped fast and packaged well. Highly recommend product as well as the seller.
title: Highly recommend for extra PlayStation storage

author: Joel V
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2020
review_content: There's nothing impressive of this old fashioned design. The connector is still viable to bend if mishandled. They should have made the plug shorter or embedded a half inch deeper in order the plastic body may help secure it from bending. I wish Seagate will improve the casing with rubber bumb guards in the future. Write speed is sufficient enough for casual users. Above all somewhat satisfied but the price is worth the purchase for its capacity.
title: Nothing new but cheaper.

author: Bill Staley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2020
review_content: I rotate 3 5TB portable Seagate hard drives as backups.  One is attached to the iMac doing hourly Time Machine backups.  Two sit in drawers, one offsite.  I rotate them monthly.  So this one really had at most three months of service.  BUT it did not die until it spent 9 hours restoring to a freshly wiped iMac *I had to go back to Catalina because a crucial app did not support Big Sur).  It did the restore, which is what I have it for, so I can't complain too much.  Now when I attach it to the iMac there's a report that it is drawing too much power and it won't load.  I have not seen a hard drive die that way before (usually the computer just won't recognize them).
title: Lasted 9 months

author: Rich Swain
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2020
review_content: So far so good, with a little help from Seagate to map the drive! Hadn't done that in years..LOLAnyway now drive is mapped, and acts just like a regular drive connected to the pc, laptop, and can save files and do back-ups from phone, laptop and desktop!The next choice is streaming media from the Seagate to my Tivo! We'll see... All working well so farand password heavily encrypted , just cant trust those numb sculls anymore! The pictures reflect my modem and media drive on one side of the wall in the secure garage, and router where it gets its best coverage throughout the home in our family room! All working exquisite! I highly recommend the drive to anyone that needs a great large drive for storage, and when you travel you can access it to download photos from anywhere with a good wireless connection world wide!
title: Media drive connected to home network

author: giraffany
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2020
review_content: Yes this is compatible with Mac if you go through the trouble of reformatting it.Seagate provides instructions on how to reformat it for Mac but make sure they're the updated ones. I followed those instructions but my computer couldn't detect the hard drive. I searched online for answers and tried a bunch of different methods but couldn't fix the issue. I talked to customer support at Seagate and tried their methods but they couldn't figure it out either and recommended getting a new device. I then talked to Apple Support and tried a bunch of other methods and somehow creating a test user account on my Mac fixed the issue. I'm glad they were able to help me with the issue and I don't have to return the hard drive. BTW I have a 2019 Macbook Pro, running on Catalina 10.15.6.So yes it does work with Mac, after you reformat it (and hopefully don't run into other issues). But I don't think it's worth the hassle if you're only planning to use this with a Mac (like me).
title: MAC USERS BEWARE!

author: Doug Edwards
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2020
review_content: I bought this for backups on a desktop.  It did not work for me.  It kept on being removed from the system.  I researched the issue, and found two fixes.  Fix 1 was to make changes to the system power settings so USB devices were not powered down.  Fix 2 was to set the disk drive power off timer to never.  Neither of these changes worked.  At some point, the drive disappears from the PC and the drive would need to be disconnected and then reconnected to show up again.  I contacted Seagate for any other fixes.  After 10 minutes on hold a support person noted my issue, then put me on hold to research.  I got hung up on.  Finally just gave up and returned the drive.  This may work for you if you plan on plugging in the drive each time you use it.
title: Did not work for backups

author: Thomas S Colvin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2020
review_content: I plugged this hard drive into my computer at work one morning and it started beeping. I had only had it for two weeks, which was actually a blessing because I only had two weeks worth of new data stored on it. Thankfully I had my flash drive that I had been using with all the data still on it. I could have lost so much more had it torn up 3 months into use.  I do not recommend this device!!!  I could have been in a deep mess.
title: Plugged it in one morning about about two weeks of use and NOTHING!

author: Miggy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2020
review_content: Bought this to store all the PS4 games on my PS5. I’ve had it for a couple weeks and so far, no issues at all. The PS4 games play like they should and I can save the internal SSD storage for the PS5 games.No external power needed. I just plugged it into then PS5, it recognized the drive right away, did the PlayStation reformat, and it was ready to go.No word yet on the durability.  I’ll update the review if I have issues.
title: Works with the PS5

author: David G
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2020
review_content: I wanted an external hard drive to store my data.  I do not want it out on a server in Elbonia.  This drive is fast and sleeker than the WD Passport it will be replacing.  However, it, like the Passport, has pre-loaded software to "simplify" the backup process.  I tried to remove it, but could not get past the last few programs, probably because the drive is partitioned and I did not want the hassle of repartitioning it.  So I have two, one that uses Seagate's TookKit backup software and one the I control.  I imagine the ToolKit version is working well, but I cannot access the files on the drive.  The other one has complete backups of my hard drive, made weekly, and I could work from that drive if necessary, say when using a different computer.
title: Sleek and fast

author: Mr. Evil
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2019
review_content: So I received this drive.  Dead as a doornail right out of the box.  Tried two different cables (though the USB 3 micro B isn't doing it any favors here).  Will not register in Disk managment in Windows 10, won't register in windows explorer.Seriously, knock it off with USB 3 Micro B.  It's a garbage connector.  The ONLY thing it has going for it is its backwards compatible with Micro USB (at USB 2.0 speed).  However, that backwards compatibility comes at the cost of a robust connector.  These USB 3 Micro Bs (I know that's a mouthful) are notoriously unreliable pieces of hot garbage.  It's 2019, USB C or I won't be buying it.
title: Why the USB 3 MicroB?  WHY?  Certainly didn't help keep this drive from being DOA.

author: Tiffany
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2020
review_content: I bought this to store thousands of embroidery files I have on my computer after my WD portable hard drive failed.  I lost some of my files that I had saved directly onto the WD instead of the computer.  So decided on a different brand. I chose this one because of the good reviews on reliability. All my files fit and I had plenty of room for all my photos also.  The device seems well made and so far no issues.
title: Plenty of storage

author: Randy Wilson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2020
review_content: 16TB is a great size, and my 8TB backup drive was too full to work, so this is great. The one complaint I have is that it's quite a bit louder than my previous Seagate backup drive. The initial backup went all night, and I could clearly hear the drive head moving from across the room. But now that the first backup is complete, it shouldn't be a problem very often. (Unless I'm recording or something, and a backup starts up...)
title: Huge drive, kinda loud

author: Mitchel Martin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2020
review_content: I have purchased 5 of the Seagate 8TB drives over the past 3 years. I use for backup of my commercial production company digital movie and photograph files. (I also use Seagate 2TB, 4TB and 5TB drives). This is a new version of the 8TB drive - The base is now vented for better cooling and now has a nice metal case that is smaller than the original. I've had great luck with these drives - not a single failure.
title: New version of 8TB External Drive

author: MattBianco
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2020
review_content: I work in a home office.  After using this for two days I was ready to smash it.  At first I thought it was a neighbor's AC or tool making a low rumbling sound. It turned out to be this drive.  Placing weight on it reduced the noise.  I added silicone pads to the bottom thinking it will absorb some of the vibration transferred to the desk, and it got worse.  Alas, it is so annoying it hast to go back.As a drive, it is fast enough and more compact that WD units.I am not sure if it can be placed on its side so it consumes less desk space.  The WD unit is vertical and therefore takes very little real estate on a desk.
title: Too About the Low Pitched Hum That Is Too Loud

author: foodie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2020
review_content: I Have to unfortunately update my review and give it one star had all of my clients work backed up on this drive and they are lost and unrecoverable. I waited 15 minutes and did manage to get it to connect once ...but before I can get my other external drives connected it failed and will not connect again. tried every trick in the book, every Google search you can think of, all the recovery software but no luck. the drive will not connect and because there is sensitive data on the drive I cannot return it even though it’s under warranty. so frustrated now I have an expensive paperweight. Recommend you either get a smaller size drive or try a different brand
title: Drive failed to mount

author: AmazonCustomer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2020
review_content: This external drive is horrible. It is literally too slow to be of any use. It may have 5 TB of storage but that does little good when you can't access it. I spent hours transferring files from my old computer (which has the outdated Windows 7 and had to be replaced) onto the drive, and while it wasn't great it seemed to get the job done. Then when I went to access them on my new computer (which works absolutely perfectly in ever other respect) I have had nothing but problems. Either there is an error, or the computer won't recognize it, or it takes 10 minutes just to open the drive. Then when it finally opens, and I try to save files from the drive to the computer...well....it has currently been 20 minutes and it is only halfway done with one file. At this rate it is going to take me 5 years to transfer my 500 GB of data. I definitely won't be able to use this as intended. Completely disappointed. This was $100 wasted.
title: Useless - Too slow to be of any use

author: Jason
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2020
review_content: Purchased this (14TB Desktop Expansion STEB14000402) as a backup drive for an external NAS RAID (4 drive RAID 10 also with a ~14TB capacity) for automatic daily backups of that system. This replaced a 3 year old 6TB Seagate Backup Plus Hub which was only able to back up more critical files due to lack of capacity. A complete backup of the RAID from scratch took about half the time it would have taken on the older drive. Certainly not as fast as SSD or a multi-drive enclosure, but for my purposes, I am backing up the multi-drive RAID to this in the event of a catastrophic failure. Very happy with the how fast and quiet the drive is for the capacity and price.
title: Huge capacity, good performance.

author: Scot Heinze
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2019
review_content: I just got my 4th Seagate portable drive. First was a 1TB, gave that to a friend when I needed more space. The 2nd one was stolen.  My 3rd one I have been using for a few years and it works great. Bought this 4th one as a backup to my other one. They are easy to use and work great for storing my music collection on it that I use when I play music at a bar or event. This new one has a plastic case though. Probably won't change how it works but I wouldn't want to use this one without the rubber case I have for it.Edit:  After closer inspection when I got this home, not only is the case plastic but it is a little larger and is a completely different model than the ones I had. So it will NOT fit in the Seagate rubber case that they sell on Amazon for &7.99.
title: Nice Hard Drive

author: zeebop9
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2020
review_content: I bought this 2TB external because of the price and portability. I didn't want the software that came with it so I reformatted it to FAT32. I have several external drives and never had this problem when formatting to FAT32. I primarily use an Apple iMac for work and everyday usage. Every time I booted up my Mac the external drive would say error and could not mount disk. I was ready to pack it up and return it but decided to reformat it again as a Mac OS Extended (Journaled) and ran it through Disk Warrior and it seems to be working now with no problems. Not sure if I can still trust this baby. The minute it hiccups or looks at me sideways, I'm sending it back..
title: Some Issues..

author: Francisco Torres Gamez
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2020
review_content: I purchased the 2 TB portable drive for my PS4 (which has only 320 GB). It greatly increased the storage of my game console although I had to use one of the only two available UBS ports. So far I have no complaints about it; the unit was easy to install; the PS4 recognized it immediately, but I had to change the settings so the PS4 used the portable as the primary storage unit and only after the PS4 reformatted the unit. Afterward I had to uninstall some of the games and reinstall them again so the PS4 would store the data in the new drive but with that out of the way, I was able to then reinstall many of the games I had to remove previously because of the lack of storage space. It's a good buy, I do recommend it. Please remember that this is is not an SSD but a hard drive.Pros: Plenty of storage, easy to install, very quiet (not totally, of course).Cons: Not as fast as an SSD.On a side note: I recommend you consider adding a battery backup (UPS) for your PS4 to protect the drives from damaged in case of brownouts or sudden blackouts. I bought a small battery backup unit for 40 US from Amazon, since 2 TB is just too much data to lose.
title: Perfect for PS4

author: James Hartley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2020
review_content: I originally got this product in January of this year.  The original was dusty when I received it.  The item was listed as new.  I thought that was very odd.  It worked great for a week or so and suddenly made grinding noises and stopped working.  I contacted the seller on Amazon and they rushed me another one.  The replacement was NOT dusty and worked great up until my time of writing which is December of the same year.  The product is no longer eligible for returns or so it says on my Amazon page and I am having difficulties seeing if I am eligible for any type of warranty or anything.I have 7 Terabytes of data on this drive that I can get back but will take an enormous amount of my personal time to do and I don't have backed up or inventoried anywhere so I will likely not get back.I will change my review if the seller is of help with my issue.  As is I like the product for the time it works despite the hassle of getting a replacement but currently im heart broken this happened.
title: Devasted lost all my data TWICE now

author: Mrs. Virginia A. Butterfield
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2020
review_content: I am returning this.  I wasted hours trying to get this to work to no avail.  First of all, the product description never mentions the drive needs an A/C power source.  OK, so I accepted that and got it powered n A/C and connected to USB.  I verified that the device humming and warn and recognized on disk manager.  However the drive would not map to a WINDOWS drive so I cannot see or access it.  I rebooted, tried multiple power plugs and multiple USB ports.  last resort I contacted SEAGATE who ultimately told me the drive was malfunctioning.  I decided I will not get a replacement but an returning for refund.  Too much aggravation and too unreliable to trust.  Very disappointed with this.. Seagate never again!
title: I am returning this.  I wasted hours trying to get this to work to no avail.

author: Mrs. Laird
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2020
review_content: Everything was going fine until I dropped my external hard drive. After the drop it worked for a few hours and then it stopped. I disconnected it from my laptop, plugged it back in and all it does is beep. My laptop no longer recognizes.  I contacted Amazon and they were willing to give me a full refund in exchange for my returning my device to them. Ummm, thanks but no thanks.  All of my data is on this device.  Amazon assured me that they would throw the hard drive away but...I'll pass. Now I am on the hunt for a new external hard drive and it will not be Seagate brand.  Yes, I know I dropped it but I feel like it should have been a little more sturdier.
title: Stopped working after 2 months!!

author: DY
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2019
review_content: Hard to believe all these positive reviews.  DO NOT BUY!  For my experience, if there was a minus rating, I would give it.  These drives and along with many other brand name drives are nothing but JUNK!  I went through three of these drives in less than a week.  Fortunately, Amazon sent replacement drives with free shipping and I ended up having Amazon refund my money.  Every replacement was just like the first - DEFECTIVE!  I couldn't even get 50+GB of data written before the drive failed while writing data.  Such a shame!  For those of you who have bought these drives and are still using them, back them up right now, because it's just a matter of time.  Hope this helps.  DO NOT BUY!
title: Pure JUNK!

author: J. Donaldson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2020
review_content: I have about 3TB of data to backup. I bought this 5TB drive to hold all of that data plus an image of my C drive. It took a couple of days which I didn't find to be excessive. I'm not running a business so copying all of that data in 1/2 the time wouldn't change my life. At any rate it worked. I keep this drive encrypted and offsite.I had been using a WD My Passport drive but after a year, and only 4 major backup copies, it died. I read where a number of other customers had the same problem. The drive blinked rapidly indicating a hardware fault. Still I have several 1TB My Passport drives that work fine. I just choose to switch to a different manufacturer's drive for this important backup. Your results may be different.I recommend this drive.
title: So far so good

author: Cecil Smith
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2020
review_content: The main reason for this review is that the hard drive slowed down tremendously right after the amazon warranty as well as some other issues so beware. The reason why I say not good for portability is because of the weight and design. For a hard drive it's quite heavy and as far as design goes the edges are very hard and sharp. You are not going to get a full 8 TB buy you will in fact get around 7. 27 TB which is crazy because that's a lot of storage that has to be used for this hard drive. Another thing to factor in is the heat. This hard drive heats up really fast so that's another thing to be concerned with. The last thing is after using it for about a couple weeks it's starting to slow down considerably.
title: Not good for portability

author: GeoLuzSurfer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2019
review_content: This hard drive is excellent if you have 1 or more terabytes of photos or videos on your PC. One should keep in mind that the true amount of storage you will have upon installing this external drive is 7.27 TB, but that is still a lot of storage for your photos and videos. I highly recommend this external drive to those who would like to free some space in their internal hard drives.
title: Lots of Storage Space

author: MRG
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2020
review_content: This backup hard drive did not operate on my Windows 10 software.  Although the computer could finally see that there was an item attached through the USB port, it could not recognize it, could not open it. The only thing I could do was uninstall it and then plug it back in, after which the icon would appear, again.  I tried different USB ports to no avail.  The Seagate representative had me try many steps, none of which would work.  I have not asked to return it because I cannot open it to see what is (or is not) accidentally on it and do not want it returned, then sent to someone else who might be able to open it.  I have another Seagate external hard drive which I received several months ago.  I was able to be used by plug and play and has been just fine.  This has been exasperating and a total waste of hours of time and money!
title: Won't work after hours of working on the problem, both myself and with Seagate live chat.

author: TC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2020
review_content: I've bought dozens of Seagate drives. This particular one arrived in a brown box without any Seagate brand packaging. This led me to believe that it was a knockoff or refurbished product. I checked the serial number with Seagate and it does appear to be a Seagate product, but NOT A NEW product. This is old or refurbished stock and the warranty expired a month ago. If you want to sell refurbs, go ahead... but at least let your customers know that they are not purchasing a new or current product instead of trying to pass it off as new.. This is just dishonest business.
title: NOT A NEW PRODUCT

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2019
review_content: Was told by Dish that the minimums  for external hard drives compatibility was 320 GB, USB 2.0, and had to have its "own power source"  So this unit filled the first 2 requirements but not the 3rd one.  GOOD NEWS.  Maybe because the unit is USB 3.0 and all 3 of the Hopper USB ports are 2.0, the unit worked fine.  So it worked fine by just connecting the USB cord between the Hopper and Seagate.  So if you are looking for an external drive to backup/download your Hopper recordings, this fills the bill!!!  The only negative is the transfer speed is not great due I think to the Hopper being only USB 2.0.  But just start the transfer at bedtime and everything will be on the hardrive when you get up.  Would buy again if I somehow fill up the current drive!!MK
title: WORKS WITH DISH HOPPER

author: #askmisspatience
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2020
review_content: Two old storage devices are in the brink of failure. They only typically last so many years.Me, in ignorance also screwed up one storage device for about six years ago or so.I was able to plug in the old devices and drop me drag storage of both to this 2TB Drive.This requires a lot of time. So, before bed. Finished in the morning. Done.Now I'm excited to have almost 20 years of writing, photos, etc backed up.I know cloud is the big thing. I'd rather not. Now, for the process of printing off what I’m keeping to hand down and for writing being used for a novel.⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
title: Works perfectly for my needs

author: R. A. Halter
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2020
review_content: This review is for the Seagate portable Backup+ 5TB hard drive.  I purchased this several months ago, to use as storage for TV shows I recorded off Tivo or ripped from my DVD and Blu-ray collection, for use with my Plex server.There's not much to say.  I have over 120 series stored on it, some with more than 1 or 2 seasons, and still have almost a terabyte left.  I don't know much about the technical side, so I can't tell you anything about seek times or benchmarks, or whatever.  I plugged it in and Windows 7 picked it up immediately.  I got rid of the software the drive came with, as it's unnecessary, formatted the drive, and started putting my TV shows on it.  The only noticeable lag is when my computer slows down because it has a motherboard and CPU from about 10 years ago or so, and Windows is a notorious resource hog.I will definitely get another if/when I fill this one up.
title: It's a portable hard drive and it just works

author: Dion White
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2019
review_content: Evertime I've used this I've gotten an error. The problem is thing is multiple terabytes of storage and I've used about 400gb the store important pictures and data.
